template.name: AWS_Distributed Load Testing
template.desc:
Distributed Load Testing on AWS automates performance testing at scale, demonstrating how systems behave under different load conditions and helping identify potential performance issues throughout their lifecycle. This solution simulates user transactions ranging from hundreds to millions by automatically launching and managing distributed test runners within and across AWS Regions, without manual user or server provisioning and providing insights into crucial areas such as the scalability and reliability of your Amazon EC2 instances, Amazon ECS or Amazon EKS, AWS Lambda function performance, Amazon RDS database query performance, and Amazon CloudFront response times.

The product supports JMeter, K6, and Locust testing frameworks and provides comprehensive analytics capabilities. Easily set test baselines to compare results throughout your application lifecycle and deploy the optional MCP server to build AI-powered analytics. You can streamline test execution, analyze regression over time, and gain deeper visibility into system behavior.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

References

  • A new type of long-lived key on AWS: Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

  • AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy reference

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

References

  • Gitleaks rule for Bedrock long-term keys

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive auditing and monitoring of all API calls and actions made through AWS API Gateway, configure AWS CloudTrail to record these activities. This setup is critical for maintaining a transparent and secure environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail: Make sure AWS CloudTrail is enabled in your AWS account. CloudTrail records all API calls made to AWS services, including API Gateway, and stores the log files in an S3 bucket.
    AWS CloudTrail Documentation
  2. Create a Trail: Create a trail to capture all API Gateway calls. A trail configuration allows you to capture management and data events for API Gateway resources.
    Creating a CloudTrail Trail
  3. Configure Logging for API Gateway: Ensure that API Gateway logging is enabled. You can configure it in the API Gateway console under the logging settings for each API stage.
    Setting up CloudWatch API Logging for API Gateway
  4. Verify Logging and Monitoring: Consistently monitor the logs produced in CloudTrail and CloudWatch. This proactive measure will help in early detection of any unauthorized or suspicious activities.
    AWS Security Hub Recommended Standards

By following these steps, you will enhance the visibility and security of your AWS API Gateway environment, ensuring that all activities are recorded and monitored effectively.

reference.name: 3.1 - Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions
4.11 - Ensure Network Access Control List (NACL) changes are monitored

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure compliance and detect unauthorized changes in your AWS API Gateway resources, use AWS Config to continuously monitor and evaluate their configurations. AWS Config provides a detailed view of the AWS resource configurations, their relationships, and changes over time.

Heres a step-by-step guide for cloud engineers to implement this control:

  1. Enable AWS Config in your AWS account. Follow the documentation to set up AWS Config by defining an IAM role with the necessary permissions, specifying an S3 bucket to store configuration snapshots, and selecting the AWS resources you want to monitor.
  2. Create a Config Rule to evaluate the configuration of your API Gateway resources. AWS Config provides a set of managed rules, or you can create custom rules using AWS Lambda. For API Gateway, you might use the AWS-managed rule called "api-gateway-gateway-response-check", which checks for best practices and compliance.
  3. Use the AWS Config console or CLI to associate the rules with the API Gateway resources. Define the compliance criteria that the rule will evaluate, such as specific security configurations or limits.
  4. Set up notifications for non-compliance using Amazon SNS. This can help in alerting teams instantaneously if there are unauthorized changes or misconfigurations detected.
  5. Regularly review the compliance status and history of changes in the AWS Config dashboard to maintain best practices and ensure security measures are consistently applied.

Refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices for more details on maintaining a secure configuration for your API Gateway resources.

reference.name: 3.3 - Ensure AWS Config is enabled in all regions

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon CloudWatch alarms
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure robust security monitoring of your API Gateway, it's critical to leverage Amazon CloudWatch metrics and alarms. This proactive measure will aid in the prompt detection and response to any anomalies or potential security issues.

Begin by accessing the Amazon CloudWatch console within AWS Management Console. Navigate to the "Metrics" section to ensure you are monitoring the relevant metrics for API Gateway. Key metrics to focus on include:

  • 4XXError: Counts the number of client-side errors (useful for detecting potential abuse).
  • 5XXError: Counts the number of server-side errors (indicates the health of the backend or integration).
  • Count: Number of API requests received (to identify unusual spikes in traffic).
  • Latency: Measures the time taken from the API Gateway receiving a request until it responds (to detect performance degradation).

After identifying these metrics, set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify your security team when any of the thresholds are breached. To do this:

  1. In the CloudWatch console, go to "Alarms" and click on "Create Alarm".
  2. Select the API Gateway metric you want to monitor, such as 4XXError or 5XXError.
  3. Define the appropriate thresholds based on your security policy. For instance, configure an alarm to trigger if the 5XXError exceeds a specific number within a predetermined timeframe.
  4. Set up notification actions, such as sending an alert to an AWS SNS topic, which will forward the notification to the relevant personnel via email or SMS.
  5. Optionally, automate responses using AWS Lambda functions to handle detected anomalies, like throttling suspicious IPs or alerting a security operations center (SOC).

Additionally, ensure compliance with security best practices by reviewing the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation regularly.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure that resources within AWS API Gateway are only accessible by authorized entities, it is pivotal to utilize IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Implementing this countermeasure involves creating precise and restrictive IAM policies that grant the minimum necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their functions.

Follow these steps to implement IAM policies based on the principle of least privilege:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the exact permissions needed by each user, role, or service account to interact with AWS API Gateway. Avoid granting broad permissions that are not necessary.
  2. Create Custom IAM Policies: Write custom IAM policies that define granular permissions. Use specific actions (e.g., `apigateway:GET`, `apigateway:POST`) and restrict access to the necessary resources (e.g., specific API IDs or stages).
  3. Apply the Policies: Attach the custom IAM policies to the relevant IAM users, groups, or roles. Ensure that the policies are evaluated and tested to confirm they provide the intended access without excess permissions.
  4. Enable Policy Versioning and Logging: Maintain policy versioning to keep track of changes and use AWS CloudTrail for monitoring and logging API Gateway access activity, which helps in auditing and compliance.
  5. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the permissions and update IAM policies as needed to adapt to any changes in requirements or security posture.

For more detailed information and best practices on securing your API Gateway using IAM policies, refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Implement logging
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all activities occurring in your AWS API Gateway, it is essential to implement monitoring and logging mechanisms using Amazon CloudWatch Logs or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. This practice aligns with the security guidelines as specified in the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable API Gateway Execution Logging: Access the API Gateway in the AWS Management Console and navigate to the stage settings. Under the Logs/Tracing tab, enable Access Logging and specify the CloudWatch Logs group. Follow the detailed instructions in the API Gateway Logging Setup Guide.
  2. Set up CloudWatch Logs: If using CloudWatch Logs, ensure that the necessary IAM roles and permissions are in place to allow API Gateway to write logs. Configure log retention policies according to your organizational compliance requirements.
  3. Implement Kinesis Data Firehose: If opting for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, create a delivery stream to capture the logs and optionally transform and load them into destination services such as Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Elasticsearch Service. For integration, refer to Creating an Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose Delivery Stream.
  4. Review and Monitor Logs: Regularly review the logs to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to alert your security team of any suspicious activities.
By adhering to these guidelines and leveraging CloudWatch Logs or Kinesis Data Firehose, you can enhance the security posture of your API Gateway by maintaining comprehensive visibility and traceability of API operations.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Security Hub
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Security Hub provides a comprehensive view of security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts for API Gateway implementations. By integrating AWS Security Hub with your AWS API Gateway, you can effectively manage and monitor security risks and ensure adherence to best practices. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:
  1. Enable AWS Security Hub: Start by enabling AWS Security Hub in the AWS Management Console. Navigate to the Security Hub dashboard and select "Get Started." Ensure it's activated in the appropriate AWS region where your API Gateway resources are hosted.

    Reference: Setting Up AWS Security Hub

  2. Configure Findings and Insights: AWS Security Hub aggregates findings from various AWS services. Ensure that findings from AWS API Gateway are included. Inspect and prioritize these findings to understand the security and compliance status.

    Reference: Understanding Findings

  3. Enable Security Standards: Activate relevant security standards like the AWS Foundational Security Best Practices standard to receive automated checks for common security configurations and vulnerabilities in your API Gateway setup.

    Reference: AWS Foundational Security Best Practices

  4. Regularly Review and Act: Regularly review the insights and findings provided by Security Hub. Implement recommended actions, such as applying least privilege principles, enabling logging and monitoring, and ensuring proper API Gateway configuration as advised in the AWS API Gateway security best practices.

    Reference: API Gateway Security Best Practices

By systematically implementing these steps, you can ensure that your AWS API Gateway environments are securely managed and compliant with established security best practices.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured IAM policies can create vulnerabilities by allowing unauthorized users to access and manipulate API Gateway resources, leading to security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who exploit weak or overly permissive IAM policies to gain access to API Gateway resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exposure of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies an IAM policy that grants overly broad permissions and uses it to access and modify API Gateway settings, potentially disrupting services or exfiltrating data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Non-compliance with security best practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failing to continuously monitor and adhere to security best practices can expose the system to vulnerabilities and lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include cyber attackers, malicious insiders, and even accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors can be as diverse as exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, pivoting through misconfigured services, and taking advantage of outdated security frameworks.
Impacts
The impacts may include data breaches, financial losses, legal penalties, damage to reputation, and disruption of business operations. Regulatory non-compliance can result in fines and restrictions on business activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A cyber attacker identifies unpatched vulnerabilities in the API Gateway and exploits them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. 2. Due to lack of continuous monitoring, an internal user accidentally misconfigures security settings, exposing critical resources to the internet. 3. Failure to adhere to encryption best practices leads to data being transmitted in plaintext, which is intercepted by an attacker.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Delayed threat detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without continuous monitoring and alerting, security threats may go undetected for extended periods, increasing the likelihood of significant damage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors can exploit vulnerabilities in your AWS infrastructure that are not promptly identified due to inadequate monitoring and alerting systems. This includes issues like unpatched software, misconfigurations, and unauthorized access attempts.
Impacts
Delayed detection can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, data loss, and potentially significant downtime. There can also be financial repercussions, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to your AWS API Gateway due to a misconfiguration. Without monitoring, this unauthorized activity goes unnoticed, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data over a prolonged period.
2. A vulnerability in an API is exploited, but because continuous monitoring is not in place, the breach is discovered only after considerable damage has been done.
3. An insider modifies configurations maliciously, leading to data leaks or system downtimes that are only detected after client complaints.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unmonitored changes and activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging, unauthorized changes and activities can go unnoticed, leading to potential vulnerabilities and compliance issues.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees or external attackers making unauthorized changes, malicious activities occurring within the AWS environment.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, non-compliance with industry regulations, potential financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal employee alters API configurations without authorization, leading to data exposure. An attacker exploits an API vulnerability, and the lack of logging prevents early detection and response. Audits reveal insufficient logging, resulting in compliance fines.

threat.name: Lack of audit trails
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without audit trails, it is challenging to track changes and access patterns to API Gateway resources, increasing the risk of undetected security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers, internal malicious users, or even compromised legitimate users. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access, modification of API configurations, and attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in the API.
Impacts
The lack of audit trails can lead to severe impacts including data breaches, unauthorized access, unnoticed manipulation of sensitive information, and difficulties in incident response and forensic investigation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An external attacker gains access to API Gateway and modifies API configurations to exfiltrate sensitive data without detection. 2. An internal employee with malicious intent changes configurations and accesses sensitive customer data, remaining undetected due to the lack of audit trails. 3. A legitimate users account is compromised and used to exploit an API vulnerability, causing data leakage and operational disruptions without raising any alarms.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Configuration drift
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unmonitored configuration changes can lead to configuration drift, making the environment non-compliant with security policies and prone to vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel, accidental misconfigurations, or insider threats making untracked changes to the configuration settings.
Impacts
Breach of security policies, increased vulnerability to attacks, potential data breaches, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider makes a change to the API Gateway configuration that disables logging, making it difficult to detect malicious activities. Unknown to the security team, an attacker exploits the misconfigured resource, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Configure origin access control to restrict CloudFront distribution access
countermeasure.desc: To enhance the security of your AWS CloudFront distributions, implement Origin Access Control (OAC) to restrict access to your origin servers. By configuring OAC, you ensure that only CloudFront has the necessary permissions to fetch content from the origin, preventing unauthorized access and modifications. This control involves creating an OAC, attaching it to your CloudFront distribution, and configuring your origin server (e.g., S3 bucket, custom origin) to only accept requests signed with the OAC signature. Regularly review and update OAC settings to align with any changes in your security posture or application architecture. Refer to AWS CloudFront Security Best Practices for detailed configuration steps and requirements.

reference.name: Restrict access to an AWS origin

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all data transmission and redirect HTTP to HTTPS
countermeasure.desc: To secure data transmitted between CloudFront and both viewers and origin servers, ensure that all communication is encrypted using HTTPS. Configure your CloudFront distribution to automatically redirect all incoming HTTP requests to HTTPS, preventing unencrypted data transmission. This can be achieved by setting up a custom error response for HTTP requests or by enforcing HTTPS in the CloudFront behavior settings. By enforcing HTTPS and redirecting HTTP traffic, you protect sensitive information from being intercepted, ensuring secure communication across your entire CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Require HTTPS for communication between viewers and CloudFront

countermeasure.name: Implement signed URLs and signed cookies to restrict content access
countermeasure.desc: To ensure that only authorized users can access specific resources served by your AWS CloudFront distribution, use signed URLs and signed cookies. Signed URLs are ideal for granting temporary access to individual files, while signed cookies allow access to multiple restricted files. Configure these mechanisms to include expiration dates and IP whitelisting to further control access. Generate and manage the cryptographic keys securely to prevent unauthorized use. By implementing signed URLs and signed cookies, you can effectively restrict content access, protecting your resources from unauthorized distribution or consumption.

reference.name: Serve private content with signed URLs and signed cookies

countermeasure.name: Integrate AWS WAF with CloudFront to mitigate web exploits
countermeasure.desc: To protect your AWS CloudFront distribution from common web exploits such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS), integrate AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) with CloudFront. AWS WAF allows you to create custom rules that filter and monitor HTTP and HTTPS requests based on defined conditions. Implement predefined managed rule groups for comprehensive protection against known vulnerabilities, and configure custom rules tailored to your applications specific security requirements. Regularly review and update your WAF rules to adapt to evolving threats, ensuring that your CloudFront distribution remains secure against web-based attacks.

reference.name: Security in Amazon CloudFront

countermeasure.name: Utilize version control for CloudFront configuration management
countermeasure.desc: Implement version control to manage and track changes to your AWS CloudFront distribution configurations. This practice allows you to maintain a history of configuration changes, making it easier to identify, audit, and revert any unintended or harmful modifications. Use tools such as AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or Git to version your configuration files, enabling consistent and repeatable deployments. In case of a misconfiguration or security issue, version control provides a straightforward path to roll back to a previous stable state, ensuring the reliability and security of your CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Use file versioning to update or remove content with a CloudFront distribution

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudFront distribution
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to a CloudFront distribution occurs when an attacker gains access to the CloudFront distribution settings or content without proper authorization. This can lead to the manipulation of distribution settings, theft of sensitive data, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromised AWS credentials, insufficient access controls, exposed API keys.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized users may access or steal sensitive content.
  • Integrity: Attackers could modify distribution settings or content, leading to the distribution of malicious or incorrect information.
  • Availability: Attackers may disrupt services by altering or disabling the distribution.
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and potential legal consequences from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker uses compromised AWS credentials to access and alter CloudFront settings, redirecting users to malicious content.
  2. Scenario 2: Insufficient access controls allow a former employee to log in and disrupt the CloudFront distribution, causing service outages.
  3. Scenario 3: An exposed API key is exploited to access CloudFront configurations, resulting in unauthorized changes to content delivery.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage occurs when sensitive information is transmitted over the network without encryption. In AWS CloudFront, this happens when data moves between edge locations, clients, or origin servers using insecure protocols like HTTP, making it vulnerable to interception.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state-sponsored actors, competitors.
  • Attack Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, compromised network infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data like login credentials and personal information.
  • Integrity: Potential alteration of data in transit.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand trust and legal repercussions.
  • Financial Loss: Regulatory fines, litigation costs, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic on public Wi-Fi to steal user credentials.
  2. Scenario 2: Unencrypted software updates are intercepted and maliciously altered.
  3. Scenario 3: A state-sponsored actor intercepts unencrypted corporate data, leading to espionage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Misconfigured CloudFront distributions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description Misconfigured CloudFront distributions can lead to serious security vulnerabilities, such as unauthorized access, data exposure, or service disruptions. These misconfigurations may include improper access settings, insecure SSL/TLS configurations, or incorrect origin server permissions, making the distribution susceptible to attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, careless administrators.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of public S3 buckets, unauthorized access to CloudFront distributions, insecure SSL/TLS settings.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Potential modification of data served by CloudFront.
  • Availability: Disruptions in service or unintended public access to private content.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand image due to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An S3 bucket linked to CloudFront is left publicly accessible, allowing attackers to download sensitive files.
  2. Scenario 2: A misconfigured SSL/TLS setting allows attackers to perform a MitM attack, intercepting data between the client and CloudFront.
  3. Scenario 3: Origin server permissions are too broad, allowing unauthorized users to alter content served by CloudFront.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Content tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Content tampering occurs when an attacker alters the content delivered through a CloudFront distribution. This can involve modifying or injecting malicious code, defacing web pages, or changing the data served to end-users. Such tampering can lead to a variety of harmful outcomes, including the distribution of malware, misinformation, or unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in origin servers, unauthorized access to CloudFront configurations, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Impacts

  • Integrity: Altered content can mislead users, distribute malware, or damage trust.
  • Reputation: Users may lose trust in the organization due to the distribution of tampered or harmful content.
  • Legal and Compliance: Organizations may face legal action or fines if tampered content results in harm to users or violates regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker gains unauthorized access to the origin server and modifies the web application files, causing users to download malware.
  2. Scenario 2: A hacker intercepts and alters data being transmitted from the origin to CloudFront, leading to the delivery of defaced or misleading content.
  3. Scenario 3: A malicious insider modifies content on an origin server that is distributed via CloudFront, resulting in the display of unauthorized or offensive material.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1492 - Stored Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Capture CloudWatch API activity with CloudTrail and secure S3 storage
countermeasure.desc:
Record every call to Amazon CloudWatch and CloudWatch Logs APIswhether it comes from the console, an SDK, or another AWS serviceby creating a multi-Region CloudTrail trail and delivering the events to a dedicated, protected Amazon S3 bucket. This preserves a tamper-evident audit log that security teams can query and retain long-term.

Implementation guidance

  1. Create or update the trail
    • In the CloudTrail console (or IaC), create a new organization or account trail and enable across all Regions so region-scoped CloudWatch actions are captured.
    • Log Management events Read + Write (these include every cloudwatch:* and logs:* API). No extra data-event selector is required.
  2. Deliver to a hardened S3 bucket
    • Choose or create a bucket in a log-archive account.
    • Block public access, disable ACLs, and add a bucket policy that:
    • {
       "Effect": "Deny",
       "Principal": "*",
       "Action": "s3:*",
       "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::cw-trail-logs/*", "arn:aws:s3:::cw-trail-logs"],
       "Condition": {"Bool": {"aws:SecureTransport": "false"}}
      }
    • Enable SSE-KMS encryption and versioning; turn on log file validation to detect tampering.
  3. Retention and analysis
    • Set an S3 lifecycle rule to transition older logs to Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive after your compliance retention window (e.g., 90 days Glacier, delete after 7 years).
    • Optionally stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon Athena table for real-time alerting and ad-hoc queries.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable AWS Config rules such as cloudtrail-enabled and s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited to ensure the trail and bucket stay compliant.
    • Alert on StopLogging, DeleteTrail, or S3 policy changes via EventBridge SNS/ChatOps.
  5. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, verify that new Regions are still covered and that the KMS key policy allows only the logging account to encrypt/decrypt.
    • Re-run an integrity check with aws cloudtrail validate-logs during incident response exercises.

Implementing this control guarantees that every CloudWatch action is immutably logged and stored in a bucket that meets the principle of least privilege, supporting forensic analysis and regulatory retention.

references

  • Logging CloudWatch API and console operations with CloudTrail
  • CloudTrail security best practices

PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented

countermeasure.name: Continuously evaluate CloudWatch resources with Security Hub and AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Activate AWS Security Hub (AWS Foundational Security Best Practices or other relevant standards) and AWS Config to run compliance checks against every Amazon CloudWatch resourcelog groups, alarms, dashboards, Contributor Insights rules, and metric filterson a rolling basis:

  1. Turn on Security Hub in all Regions (or via AWS Organizations) and enable the standard that contains the CloudWatch controls (for example, CW_LOGS_1 Enable VPC Flow Logs alarms). Findings automatically surface when a log group, alarm, or metric filter violates the control.
  2. Enable AWS Config recording and deploy the Operational Best Practices for Amazon CloudWatch conformance pack (or choose individual managed rules such as CLOUDWATCH_ALARM_ACTION_CHECK and CLOUDWATCH_LOG_GROUP_ENCRYPTED). These rules evaluate resource configuration at creation and on every drift event.
  3. Set up aggregation & alerting
    • Aggregate Security Hub findings to the delegated administrator account; forward high-severity CloudWatch findings to an SNS topic integrated with your ticketing/on-call system.
    • Use AWS Config aggregators or a central dashboard (Config History + Security Hub Insights) to view compliance trends across accounts and Regions.
  4. Automate remediation Attach EventBridge rules to specific finding types (e.g., missing encryption) that invoke an SSM Automation or Lambda function to apply the correct setting, then mark the finding RESOLVED.
  5. Governance & review
    • Include the conformance pack template and any custom Config rules in your IaC repository; fail CI/CD builds if they are removed.
    • Review rule parameters (log-group prefixes, alarm thresholds, required encryption keys, etc.) quarterly and update them as new CloudWatch features or compliance clauses appear.

By combining Security Hubs managed controls with AWS Configs rule engine, you gain continuous, standards-based assurance that CloudWatch is configured securely and remains compliant as your environment evolves.

references

  • Security Hub controls for CloudWatch
  • Operational Best Practices for Amazon CloudWatch

countermeasure.name: Encrypt CloudWatch logs at rest with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Secure every Amazon CloudWatch Logs log group by associating it with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of relying on the default, AWS-owned key. A CMK lets you define your own rotation schedule, attach restrictive key policies, and audit every decrypt operation.

Implementation checklist

  1. Create or select a CMK
    • aws kms create-key --description "CloudWatch Logs CMK"
    • Enable automatic rotation (every 365 days) or schedule key rotation manually.
  2. Lock down the key policy
    • Add the CloudWatch Logs service principallogs.<region>.amazonaws.comwith encrypt/decrypt permissions.
    • Optionally restrict use to the specific log-group ARN with an kms:EncryptionContext:aws:logs:arn condition.
  3. Associate the CMK with each log group
    • New groups: aws logs create-log-group --log-group-name /app/orders --kms-key-id <CMK-ARN>
    • Existing groups: aws logs associate-kms-key --log-group-name /app/orders --kms-key-id <CMK-ARN>
    • Update IaC templates (CloudFormation/Terraform) so encryption is declared at build time and drift-detection fails when no key is set.
  4. Verify encryption
    • aws logs describe-log-groups --log-group-name-prefix /app/orders --query "logGroups[*].kmsKeyId" should return the CMK ARN.
    • Run a sample PutLogEvents; confirm CloudTrail shows Decrypt events that reference the CMK.
  5. Monitor and rotate
    • Enable CloudWatch alarms on kms:Disabled or kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion events for the CMK.
    • Rotate or retire keys via a controlled change window; re-associate log groups with the new CMK before disabling the old one.
  6. Continuous compliance
    • Deploy the AWS Config rule cloudwatch-log-group-encrypted (or similar) and alert when a group lacks SSE-KMS.
    • Include a Security Hub/FSBP control to surface non-encrypted groups at the account level.

Following this procedure guarantees that all log data is encrypted with keys you control, meeting regulatory requirements for data confidentiality, key management, and separation of duties.

References

  • Encrypt log data in CloudWatch Logs using AWS Key Management Service
  • CloudWatch logs are not encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ and perfect forward secrecy for CloudWatch API communications
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudWatch endpoints already refuse TLS 1.0/1.1, but every client you manage must also negotiate TLS 1.2 or newer and present a cipher suite that offers perfect forward secrecy (PFS)for example, any suite that starts with ECDHE_ or DHE_. This prevents downgrade attacks and meets AWSs minimum-encryption requirement.

Implementation checklist

  1. Update runtimes and libraries
    • OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181+, .NET 4.6+, AWS CLI v2, and current AWS SDK releases all default to TLS 1.2.
    • In base images or AMIs, set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 (OpenSSL) or equivalent.
  2. Disable legacy protocols and weak suites
    • Web proxies or forwarders: ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3; ssl_prefer_server_ciphers off;.
    • Container or OS hardening scripts should strip TLSv1/TLSv1.1 and static-key suites (e.g., *_RSA_*).
  3. Add automated tests
    • CI step:
    • openssl s_client -connect monitoring.${AWS_REGION}.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 && \
       { echo " TLS 1.1 still accepted"; exit 1; } || echo " TLS 1.1 correctly rejected"
    • Repeat with -tls1_2; the handshake must succeed.
  4. Secure interface VPC endpoints
    • Allow only TCP 443 in the endpoints security group.
    • Inspect flow logs for any TLSv1/TLSv1.1 attempts and alert if they appear.
  5. Centralize enforcement
    • In AWS Organizations, attach an SCP that denies cloudwatch:* when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule or linter that fails images containing TLSv1/TLSv1.1.
  6. Continuous monitoring & patching
    • Run AWS Inspector or OS vulnerability scans monthly; rebuild AMIs/containers when OpenSSL or Java receives critical CVEs.
    • Review cipher-suite telemetry and rotate certificates if you retire old CAs.

Properly enforcing modern TLS with PFS ensures CloudWatch telemetry stays confidential and resistant to future key compromise.

References

  • Infrastructure security for CloudWatch
  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum protocol level for all AWS service API endpoints

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege CloudWatch access with IAM roles, permission boundaries, and key rotation
countermeasure.desc:
Provision every workload and human operator with only the CloudWatch actions it truly needs, delivered through temporary credentials, and ring-fence those permissions with a boundary policy:

  1. Design fine-grained policies
    • List the exact actions the principal needs (for example, logs:PutLogEvents, logs:CreateLogStream, cloudwatch:PutMetricData).
    • Scope resources precisely (arn:aws:logs:eu-west-1:123456789012:log-group:/aws/lambda/orders:*) andwhere supportedadd aws:ResourceTag or logs:LogGroupName conditions to prevent horizontal sprawl.
  2. Use roles, not long-term IAM users
    • Attach policies to service roles (EC2 instance profiles, Lambda execution roles, ECS task roles) or to federated/SSO roles for humans.
    • Disable or avoid creating IAM users altogether; they require permanent access keys.
  3. Enforce permission boundaries
    • Create an account-wide managed policy that defines the absolute maximum CloudWatch scope (for example, deny wildcard logs:* or actions outside approved Regions).
    • Attach this policy as a permissions boundary to every role so even misconfigured inline or attached policies cannot exceed it.
  4. Rotate credentials automatically
    • Where access keys are still unavoidable (build agents, legacy scripts), store them in AWS Secrets Manager and rotate on a 90-day schedule with a Lambda function or the IAM credential-report alarm.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-unused-credentials-check and alert if a key is older than the defined window or unused for 45 days.
  5. Validate continuously
    • Run IAM Access Analyzer to surface unintended CloudWatch permissions.
    • Add a CI/CD linter that fails commits introducing logs:* or cloudwatch:* wildcard privileges.
    • Stream CloudTrail events to Security Hub and raise findings on PutUserPolicy, AttachRolePolicy, or CreateAccessKey that violate the guardrails.
  6. Review regularly
    • Quarterly, prune unused log groups and metrics, then tighten policies accordingly.
    • Re-evaluate the boundary policy as new CloudWatch features (e.g., Logs Insights, cross-account metrics) are adopted.

Implementing least-privilege policies, permission boundaries, and automatic key rotation ensures CloudWatch can collect the telemetry you need without giving principals the power to tamper with, exfiltrate, or overload log and metric data.

References

  • IAM policy examples for CloudWatch Logs
  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities

countermeasure.name: Mask sensitive data in CloudWatch Logs and keep credentials out of logs
countermeasure.desc:
Protect log integrity and privacy by enabling CloudWatch Logs data-protection masking on every log group and by ensuring that no secrets or personally identifiable information (PII) are written to log messages, metric dimensions, or resource tags.

Implementation steps

  1. Attach a data-protection policy to each log group (or at the account level).
    • In the console: Logs Log groups Actions Create data protection policy.
    • Choose relevant managed data identifiers (credit-card numbers, email addresses, access keys, etc.) or add custom regex patterns.
    • Select the De-identify (mask) action so matching substrings are automatically replaced with placeholders.
  2. Block credentials and PII at the source.
    • Review application logging code; exclude secrets, access tokens, or user data from log payloads.
    • Never place sensitive values in CloudWatch metric dimensions, loggroup names, or tag keys/valuesthese fields are not run through the masking engine.
  3. Test and validate before production.
    • Send sample events containing fake identifiers; confirm they appear masked in the console and when fetched with filter-log-events.
    • Enable the Audit action in the policy to emit CloudWatch metrics (DataProtectionFindings) and create alarms on unmasked detections.
  4. Automate enforcement with IaC and guardrails.
    • Store policy JSON in Terraform/CloudFormation modules; fail the pipeline if a new log group lacks the standard policy.
    • Add AWS Config custom rules that flag metric or tag values matching forbidden patterns (for example, AKIA[0-9A-Z]{16}).
  5. Review quarterly.
    • Update the list of data identifiers as regulations evolve (GDPR, PCI DSS, HIPAA).
    • Inspect DataProtectionFindings metrics and Security Hub findings; remediate services still emitting unmasked data.

Following this control keeps secrets and PII out of your observability pipeline, satisfies compliance requirements, and reduces the risk of accidental data exposure in logs.

References

  • Help protect sensitive log data with masking
  • Understanding data protection policies in CloudWatch Logs

countermeasure.name: Require MFA for all identities and grant least-privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
Strengthen account-level security by enforcing multi-factor authentication (MFA) on every human identityroot user, IAM users, and AWS IAM Identity Center (formerly AWS SSO) userswhile granting each identity only the permissions it needs (principle of least privilege).

Implementation guidance

  1. Root user
    • Enable a hardware- or FIDO2-compliant MFA device on the root account immediately after account creation.
    • Lock the root credentials away; use them only for break-glass tasks such as account-level billing changes.
  2. IAM users (if still required)
    • Attach an IAM policy that denies * actions unless the session is authenticated with MFA ("Condition":{"Bool":{"aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent":"true"}}).
    • Enforce a strong password policy (minimum 14 characters, symbols, rotation) and disable long-lived access keys where possible.
  3. Prefer AWS IAM Identity Center (SSO)
    • Create users and groups in AWS IAM Identity Center or a connected IdP (Azure AD, Okta, etc.) instead of IAM users.
    • Assign permission sets that map to IAM roles with narrowly scoped policies (read-only, app-admin, billing-view, etc.).
    • Require MFA at the IdP level; Identity Center passes the MFA context to the temporary session.
  4. Least-privilege permission design
    • Start with AWS-managed or service-specific job-function policies as a baseline, then remove actions not required.
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer and last-accessed data to trim unused permissions regularly.
    • Apply service control policies (SCPs) in AWS Organizations to set account-wide guardrails (e.g., deny deleting CloudTrail, deny disabling MFA).
  5. Monitoring and enforcement
    • Enable AWS Config rules such as iam-user-mfa-enabled, root-account-mfa-enabled, and iam-password-policy.
    • Stream CloudTrail management events to an analytics platform; alert on DeleteVirtualMFADevice, DeactivateMFADevice, or policy changes that broaden permissions.
  6. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, audit all identities: verify MFA devices, rotate permission sets, and deactivate any unused IAM users.
    • Automate findings remediation with AWS Security Hub EventBridge Lambda to re-enable MFA or quarantine non-compliant users.

Following this control eliminates single-factor logins and minimizes blast radius by ensuring every human session is short-lived, strongly authenticated, and scoped to the minimum set of allowed actions.

References

  • Enable MFA for the root user and IAM users
  • IAM security best practices

countermeasure.name: Restrict CloudWatch VPC endpoints using IAM resource policies
countermeasure.desc:
Create a custom IAM resource policy for every interface VPC endpoint that your workloads use to send metrics or logs to Amazon CloudWatch / CloudWatch Logs. The policy must:

  • Allow only the actions each workload needs typically logs:PutLogEvents, logs:CreateLogStream, or cloudwatch:PutMetricData.
  • Restrict the callers network origin by adding either
    • aws:SourceVpc = vpc-xxxxxxxx (all traffic must come from the named VPC), or
    • aws:SourceVpce = vpce-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx (traffic must enter through the specific endpoint ID).

Example endpoint policy JSON

{
 "Version":"2012-10-17",
 "Statement":[
   {
     "Effect":"Allow",
     "Principal":"*",
     "Action":[
       "logs:PutLogEvents",
       "logs:CreateLogStream"
     ],
     "Resource":"*",
     "Condition":{
       "StringEquals":{
         "aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-0abc123def4567890"
       }
     }
   }
 ]
}

Attach a similar policy to each CloudWatch monitoring and logs endpoint; use aws:SourceVpc if the endpoint will be replaced regularly.

Implementation checklist

  1. Identify endpoints aws ec2 describe-vpc-endpoints --filters Name=service-name,Values=com.amazonaws.<region>.logs.
  2. Author the policy store the JSON in your IaC repo; parameterise the VPC or VPCE IDs.
  3. Attach the policy aws ec2 modify-vpc-endpoint-policy --vpc-endpoint-id vpce- --policy-document file://policy.json.
  4. Validate from another VPC/endpoint, attempt a disallowed action and confirm it fails with 403 AccessDenied.
  5. Monitor & rotate enable CloudTrail data events for CloudWatch Logs; alert if a denied action or a request from an unexpected VPC occurs. Review policies whenever new logging agents or VPCs are introduced.

Using least-privilege resource policies on the endpoint itself prevents rogue traffic from other VPCs or compromised routes from writing logs or metrics, even if the IAM identity has permissions.

References

  • Using CloudWatch Logs with interface VPC endpoints
  • Control access to VPC endpoints with endpoint policies

countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for CloudWatch and CloudWatch Logs
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for both Amazon CloudWatch (com.amazonaws.<region>.monitoring) and CloudWatch Logs (com.amazonaws.<region>.logs) so that all metrics and log-ingestion traffic stays on the AWS backbone and never traverses the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet & AZ planning Pick at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones; the endpoint puts an elastic network interface (ENI) in each one.
  2. Provision the endpoints
  3. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
     --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
     --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.monitoring \
     --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
     --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
     --security-group-ids sg-endpoints
    # Repeat for com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.logs
  4. Make sure Enable private DNS is turned on (default) so SDKs and agents resolve the service names to the endpoint ENIs automatically.
  5. Tighten the security group attached to the endpoint ENIsallow only TCP 443 from the CIDRs or security groups that host your producers (EC2, Lambda in VPC, containers).
  6. (Optional) attach an endpoint policy that limits actions such as cloudwatch:PutMetricData or logs:PutLogEvents and uses aws:SourceVpc/aws:SourceVpce conditions for extra defense-in-depth.
  7. Validate from a private instance:
    • dig monitoring.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com A should return a 10.x address (your ENI).
    • aws logs put-log-events should succeed without an Internet gateway or NAT.
  8. Governance Add an AWS Config rule (managed or custom) that checks every account/Region for the presence of the two endpoints and alarms if missing. Share endpoints across spoke VPCs with AWS RAM instead of duplicating them.
  9. Monitor CloudWatch publishes metrics like InterfaceEndpointActiveConnections; set alarms for connection errors or throttling to detect misconfiguration or abuse.

By routing monitoring data entirely inside your VPC, you close an unnecessary egress path, reduce latency, and align with compliance mandates that forbid public-internet traffic for observability pipelines.

References

  • Using CloudWatch with interface VPC endpoints
  • Using CloudWatch Logs with interface VPC endpoints
