customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Define autoscaling policies and set CPU/memory limits
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent resource exhaustion and ensure predictable performance by combining hard container limits with ECS Service Auto Scaling:

  1. Define hard limits in the task definition
    • For each container set both cpu and memory (MiB) hard valuese.g., cpu: 512 (0.5 vCPU) and memory: 1024 (1 GiB).
    • The container is OOM-killed if it exceeds memory or throttled when CPU is saturated, protecting co-located tasks and the host.
  2. Enable service-level target-tracking auto scaling
    • Register the service with Application Auto Scaling and choose a metric:
      • CPUUtilization or MemoryUtilization for steady workloads.
      • ALB RequestCountPerTarget when traffic is bursty.
    • Example: track CPU at 50 %when the rolling average rises above 50 %, scale-out adds tasks; below 50 %, scale-in removes tasks.
    • Set sensible guardrails: minCapacity 2 tasks (one per AZ) and maxCapacity based on subnet ENI or budget limits.
  3. Add CloudWatch alarms for over-commit
    • Alarm at 70 % CPU or 80 % memory to surface mis-sizing before throttling occurs.
    • Route alarms to PagerDuty/SNS so Ops can tune limits or increase targets.
  4. Test and tune periodically
    • Use load-testing (AWS Distributed Load Testing, Locust) at 2 historical peak; verify tasks scale before CPU or memory breaches.
    • Adjust target tracking thresholds, cooldowns (3060 s), and task sizes based on test results and cost goals.
  5. Automate compliance
    • Add CI lint rules (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fail builds when a task definition omits cpu/memory or a service lacks an auto-scaling policy.
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule to flag services whose desiredCount == maxCapacity (no headroom) or where maxCapacity == minCapacity (scaling disabled).

By capping resource usage and allowing the service to grow or shrink automatically, you avoid noisy-neighbour failures, absorb legitimate traffic spikes, and keep AWS costs in check.

References

  • Service Auto Scaling for Amazon ECS
  • CPU and memory settings in task definitions

standard.ref: ID.AM-5: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
PR.PT-5: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail, CloudWatch logs, and container insights
countermeasure.desc:
Combine control-plane, network, and runtime telemetry so you can see who changed the service, what traffic flowed, and how the containers behaved:

  1. CloudTrail (configuration changes)
    • Turn on an organization-wide, multi-Region trail.
    • Verify that events such as CreateService, UpdateService, RegisterTaskDefinition, and PutScalingPolicy are captured and delivered to an SSE-KMSencrypted S3 bucket.
    • Stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs or Security Lake so EventBridge rules can alert on risky actions (for example, a service update that bypasses deployment circuit breakers).
  2. CloudWatch Logs (network visibility)
    • Enable VPC Flow Logsversion 3for every subnet hosting ECS tasks and for the ENIs of your load balancers and NAT Gateways.
    • Store logs in CloudWatch Logs with 90-day retention; create metric filters that fire on unexpected ports, denied connections, or egress to disallowed CIDRs.
  3. Container Insights (runtime metrics & traces)
    • ECS/Fargate: aws ecs update-cluster-settings --settings name=containerInsights,value=enabled.
    • EKS: deploy the CloudWatch agent Helm chart with containerInsights=true.
    • Collect per-task and per-container CPU, memory, network I/O, and task-level events; alarm when utilisation exceeds 80 % or restart counts spike.
  4. Dashboards & alerts
    • Build CloudWatch dashboards that overlay desired vs. running tasks, Flow-Log rejects, and Container Insights CPU/memory graphs.
    • Route high-severity CloudTrail events and metric alarms to your incident channel (SNS PagerDuty/Slack).
  5. Governance & retention
    • Use AWS Config rules (vpc-flow-logs-enabled, custom ecs-container-insights-enabled, cloudtrail-enabled) so telemetry cannot be disabled without producing a finding.
    • Retain all logs for at least one year (or your compliance window) in Glacier Instant Retrieval / Deep Archive.

With CloudTrail, Flow Logs, and Container Insights enabledand wired to real-time alertsyou gain end-to-end observability for rapid incident response and audit-grade evidence.

References

  • Monitoring Amazon ECS with CloudWatch Container Insights
  • Logging and monitoring in Amazon VPC (Flow Logs, CloudTrail)

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Enable image scanning and enforce trusted image registries
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every ECS service pulls container images only from an approved registryideally Amazon ECRand that each image has passed an automated vulnerability scan and bears a valid cryptographic signature before the service can launch or scale:

  1. Restrict pull locations
    • Push production images to Amazon ECR (or an ECR pull-through cache that mirrors a curated external repo).
    • On the task-execution role, add an IAM condition that denies ecr:BatchGetImage when the repository tag Trusted true, blocking unvetted registries.
  2. Turn on vulnerability scanning
    • Enable ECR enhanced scanning / Amazon Inspector with scan-on-push for every repository.
    • Fail the CI/CD pipeline if High or Critical CVEs remain unpatched or un-waived.
    • Schedule nightly re-scans; route new findings to Security Hub or your ticket system.
  3. Require signed provenance
    • Activate ECR image signing (AWS Signer or OCI Notary v2).
    • Attach a permissions boundary that denies image pulls when ecr:ImageHasSignature is "false".
    • Reference images by digest (<repo>@sha256:) in the services task definitionnever by a mutable tag such as :latest.
  4. Continuous compliance
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule that flags a service NON_COMPLIANT if its task definition points to an image URI lacking a digest, signature, or trusted-repo tag.
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer to spot cross-account repository shares you did not intend.
  5. Key rotation & auditing
    • Store signing keys in KMS and rotate them annually; update the Signer profile and re-sign active digests.
    • Keep an inventory of approved images and retire any digest that inherits end-of-life packages.

With enforced scanning, trusted registries, and signed images, your ECS services run only vetted, tamper-proof codeclosing a major supply-chain attack vector.

References

  • Amazon ECR image scanning and signing
  • Container image signing with AWS Signer

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS (HTTPS) on load balancer target groups
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that all traffic flowing from an internet-facing Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB) to your ECS tasks is encrypted in-transit:

  1. Create secure listeners
    • On the load balancer expose port 443 with an ACM certificate and an AWS security policy that requires TLS 1.2 or newer with PFS ciphers (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Delete or redirect any port 80 listener so plaintext HTTP is never served.
  2. Convert target groups to HTTPS/TLS
    • Set the target group protocol to HTTPS (ALB) or TLS (NLB).
    • Update health checks to use the same secure port/path; enable certificate validation if your tasks present public CA or ACM certificates.
    • Ensure every task container listens on 443 (or your chosen secure port) and presents a valid certificateeven a self-signed one if you disable validation.
  3. Lock down network paths
    • In target-side security groups allow inbound 443/TCP only from the load balancers SG; remove any open 80/TCP rules.
    • Delete the default outbound all traffic rule; add explicit egress rules for required destinations (for example, HTTPS to VPC endpoints).
  4. Automate compliance
    • Add CI/CD linting (cfn-nag, Checkov, CloudFormation Guard) that fails if a target group protocol is HTTP or if a public LB exposes port 80.
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule (or Security Hub control) that marks a load balancer NON_COMPLIANT when any listener uses TLS 1.0/1.1 or any target group runs on HTTP.
  5. Monitor & rotate
    • Alarm on CloudWatch metrics such as TargetTLSNegotiationErrorCount and ALB HTTPCode_Target_5XX_Countspikes often indicate expired or mis-matched certificates.
    • Use ACM for automatic public-cert renewal; for internal certificates, rotate on a defined schedule and verify by re-running health checks.

End-to-end TLS protects data from eavesdropping or tampering both on the public internet and inside your VPC, meeting modern compliance requirements and hardening your ECS service against downgrade attacks.

References

  • HTTPS listeners for Application Load Balancers
  • TLS listeners for Network Load Balancers

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege for task execution and task roles
countermeasure.desc:
For every ECS service, define two separate IAM rolesone the platform needs (task-execution role) and one your code needs (task role)and keep each roles policy to the smallest possible set of actions and resources.

1. task-execution role (ECS housekeeping only)
Allow just these capabilities, scoped to specific ARNs:

  • Pull image: ecr:GetAuthorizationToken, ecr:BatchGetImage, ecr:GetDownloadUrlForLayer your ECR repos.
  • Write logs: logs:CreateLogStream, logs:PutLogEvents the services log group.
  • Decrypt secrets (optional): kms:Decrypt + secretsmanager:GetSecretValue only the secrets/KMS keys referenced in the task definition.

Start with the AWS-managed policy AmazonECSTaskExecutionRolePolicy, then delete any service you dont use.

2. task (application) role (container code)

  • List only the AWS APIs the container callse.g., dynamodb:PutItem, sqs:SendMessage.
  • Lock Resource to exact ARNs (one table, one queue, one bucket prefix).
  • Add context conditions so permissions work only inside the intended environment, for example:

"Condition": {
 "StringEquals": { "aws:SourceVpc": "vpc-0abc123" },
 "StringEqualsIfExists": { "aws:CalledVia": "ecs-tasks.amazonaws.com" }
}

3. guardrails

  • Attach a permission boundary that denies any role granting Action:"*" or Resource:"*" without conditions.
  • Fail CI/CD builds when a task definition references a role lacking the boundary or containing wildcards.
  • Enable IAM Access Analyzer unused permissions and prune actions not seen in CloudTrail for 90 days.

This two-role, context-scoped design ensures a compromised container can touch only the resources it truly needs, sharply reducing blast radius.

References

  • IAM roles for Amazon ECS tasks
  • Grant least privilege in IAM

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Restrict security groups and place tasks in private subnets
countermeasure.desc:
Keep containers off the public Internet and block unnecessary east-west traffic by launching every ECS service in private subnets (no route to the Internet Gateway) and attaching a locked-down security group (SG):

  1. Subnet placement
    • In the service or task definitions awsvpcConfiguration, list only subnet IDs whose route tables dont send 0.0.0.0/0 (or ::/0) to an IGW.
    • Provide outbound access via a NAT Gateway or, better, interface VPC endpoints for S3, STS, DynamoDB, etc.
    • Verify with Reachability Analyzer that the task ENI cant reach the IGW directly.
  2. Security-group hardening
    • Ingress usually none; tasks initiate traffic out. If another internal service must call the task, allow only that services SG on the exact port.
    • Egress delete the default all-traffic rule. Add:
      • TCP 443 to VPC-endpoint SGs or NAT CIDR.
      • DB ports to the RDS SG if required.
    • Never expose 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 on any port.
  3. Automated guardrails
    • Add CI linting (Checkov, cfn-nag, CloudFormation Guard) that fails if a task definition references a public subnet or an SG with open CIDRs.
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule that flags services NON_COMPLIANT when their subnets include an IGW route or their SG allows unrestricted egress.
  4. Monitor & review
    • Enable VPC Flow Logs on private subnets; alarm on flows that hit public IP ranges outside AWS service prefixes.
    • Re-audit subnet routes and SG rules each quarter; remediate any drift from least-privilege design.

Isolating tasks in private subnets cuts inbound attack surface to zero, while restrictive SG rules stop lateral movement and accidental data leaks.

References

  • Task networking patterns and private subnets Amazon ECS
  • Security groups for your VPC best practices

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insufficient scaling configuration causing resource exhaustion
threat.desc:
General Description

In AWS ECS, improper scaling configuration can lead to resource exhaustion when traffic surges or workloads increase. This results in service unavailability or degraded performance due to the ECS cluster failing to scale adequately.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Trigger traffic spikes (e.g., DDoS attacks).
  • Misconfiguration: Inadequate auto-scaling policies.
  • Application Bugs: Memory leaks causing resource hogging.
  • Legitimate Users: Unintentionally triggering heavy processes.

Impacts

  • Service Unavailability: Crashes or unresponsiveness.
  • Performance Degradation: Increased latency and downtime.
  • Financial Costs: Unplanned resource scaling charges.
  • Security Risks: Reduced incident response capability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. DDoS Attack: Traffic spike exhausts resources, causing downtime.
  2. Misconfigured Scaling: Conservative limits fail during peak load.
  3. Application Bug: Memory leak exhausts container resources.
  4. Traffic Surge: Popular service overwhelms cluster capacity.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Unhealthy task replacements leading to downtime
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, unhealthy tasks may automatically be replaced based on health checks and service definitions. If replacements consistently fail or the root issue persists, it can result in prolonged downtime and service disruption.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Misconfiguration: Incorrect health check settings or service definitions.
  • Application Bugs: Faulty containerized applications failing health checks.
  • Infrastructure Issues: Underlying host or network failures.
  • Excessive Restart Loops: Continuous attempts to restart unhealthy tasks.

Impacts:

  • Service Downtime: Applications become unavailable or unstable.
  • Performance Degradation: Increased response time due to failed replacements.
  • Financial Costs: Increased resource usage from repeated task restarts.
  • Operational Overhead: Manual intervention required to resolve failed tasks.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Misconfigured Health Checks: Misconfigured interval leads to frequent task replacement, causing downtime.
  2. Buggy Application: Repeatedly fails health checks, triggering replacement loops.
  3. Infrastructure Glitch: Host failure causes multiple task replacements without resolving the root cause.
  4. High Availability Failure: Misconfiguration prevents successful task distribution across availability zones.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Task execution role with excessive IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, task execution roles define the permissions that tasks can use when interacting with AWS services. If these roles have excessive IAM permissions, they increase the attack surface and can be exploited to access sensitive resources or escalate privileges within the AWS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Exploit compromised tasks to gain broader AWS access.
  • Misconfiguration: Assigning overly permissive policies to tasks.
  • Insider Threats: Misuse of legitimate access granted to tasks.
  • Compromised Container: Malicious code within the container abuses elevated permissions.

Impacts:

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored in AWS services.
  • Privilege Escalation: Compromised tasks gain access to critical resources.
  • Service Disruption: Misuse of permissions to stop, modify, or delete ECS resources.
  • Financial Loss: Abuse of permissions to initiate costly AWS services.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Privilege Escalation: An attacker gains control of a task with administrator-level permissions and compromises the entire AWS environment.
  2. Data Exfiltration: A containerized application with access to S3 inadvertently exposes data to unauthorized users.
  3. Misconfiguration: An ECS task role is assigned the AdministratorAccess policy, allowing unintended AWS API calls.
  4. Malicious Code Execution: A compromised container runs commands to list, delete, or alter resources in AWS.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Container image vulnerabilities deployed by service
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, deploying containers with unpatched vulnerabilities exposes the system to security risks. These vulnerabilities may arise from outdated base images, unpatched libraries, or insecure configurations, potentially leading to exploitation during runtime.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Exploit known vulnerabilities within container images.
  • Developers/Operators: Deploy images without thorough security checks.
  • Automated CI/CD Pipelines: Deploy vulnerable images due to inadequate security testing.
  • Compromised Public Images: Use of untrusted or outdated images from public repositories.

Impacts:

  • Service Compromise: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities to gain control.
  • Data Breach: Unsecured containers expose sensitive information.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised containers are used to infiltrate other ECS tasks or services.
  • Service Disruption: Exploits cause crashes or resource hijacking (e.g., cryptomining).

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Unpatched Base Image: An outdated base image with a critical vulnerability allows remote code execution.
  2. Library Vulnerability: A vulnerable open-source library within the container is exploited to gain shell access.
  3. Malicious Public Image: A container pulled from an untrusted registry contains embedded malware.
  4. Insecure Configuration: Misconfigured container security settings allow privilege escalation within the ECS task.

threat.name: Unencrypted service traffic between load balancer and tasks
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, traffic between the load balancer and ECS tasks may be transmitted without encryption if not explicitly configured. This lack of encryption can expose sensitive data to interception, tampering, or eavesdropping, especially in multi-tenant environments or untrusted networks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Network Attackers: Intercept unencrypted traffic within the VPC or through compromised network nodes.
  • Insider Threats: Internal users with network access capture unencrypted communications.
  • Misconfiguration: Load balancer listeners not configured for HTTPS or TLS.
  • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Exploit unencrypted channels to inject or steal data.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Sensitive data exposed to interception.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Unencrypted traffic may be modified in transit.
  • Compliance Violations: Lack of encryption may breach regulatory standards (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA).
  • Reputation Damage: Breach of confidential data impacts customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Sniffing Unencrypted Data: An attacker intercepts HTTP traffic between the load balancer and ECS tasks, extracting credentials or sensitive information.
  2. Session Hijacking: Unencrypted session tokens are stolen, allowing unauthorized access.
  3. MitM Attack: An attacker within the VPC manipulates unencrypted traffic, injecting malicious responses.
  4. Misconfiguration: The load balancer is configured to use HTTP instead of HTTPS, exposing data in transit.

threat.name: Network exposure of service tasks
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, improper network configuration can expose service tasks to the internet or untrusted networks, increasing the risk of unauthorized access, data exfiltration, or service disruption. Exposed tasks are vulnerable to attacks such as unauthorized API calls, data leaks, and external intrusions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Exploit publicly accessible endpoints to compromise services.
  • Misconfigured Network Policies: Improper security group or VPC configurations exposing tasks.
  • Insider Threats: Access exposed tasks from within the organization.
  • Automated Scanners: Identify and exploit exposed IPs and open ports.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Sensitive data exposed through public-facing tasks.
  • Service Downtime: Exploits cause crashes or service interruptions.
  • Lateral Movement: Attackers gain access to other AWS resources via compromised tasks.
  • Financial Loss: Abuse of exposed services (e.g., for cryptomining).

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Public Endpoint Exposure: A task running a web application is mistakenly configured to be publicly accessible, allowing attackers to exploit application vulnerabilities.
  2. Improper Security Groups: Open ports in the ECS task's security group allow unauthorized SSH access.
  3. Misconfigured VPC: A task intended for internal use is accessible from the internet, leading to data exposure.
  4. Internal Pivoting: An attacker compromises a publicly exposed task and uses it to access other internal services within the VPC.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Lack of visibility into service activity and events
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, insufficient monitoring and logging reduce visibility into service activity and events, leading to delayed detection of anomalies, potential breaches, or operational issues. This lack of insight makes it difficult to identify suspicious activities, configuration changes, or performance degradation.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Attackers: Exploit blind spots to perform malicious activities without detection.
  • Internal Threats: Misuse privileges without leaving a trace.
  • Misconfiguration: Inadequate setup of logging and monitoring services.
  • System Failures: Undetected errors or crashes affect availability.

Impacts:

  • Delayed Incident Response: Slow detection of breaches or failures.
  • Operational Inefficiency: Lack of metrics to optimize performance and resource usage.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to meet auditing requirements.
  • Undetected Attacks: Malicious activities go unnoticed, increasing risk.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Undetected Data Exfiltration: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities without triggering alerts due to inadequate logging.
  2. Configuration Changes: Unauthorized modifications to ECS task definitions go unnoticed, leading to potential compromise.
  3. Missed Performance Issues: A memory leak in a container remains undetected, causing resource exhaustion.
  4. Service Disruption: Critical ECS tasks crash without generating alerts, resulting in downtime.

weakness.name: CWE-215
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-215: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code The product inserts sensitive information into debugging code, which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production. When debugging, it may be necessary to report detailed information to the programmer. However, if the debugging code is not disabled when the product is operating in a production environment, then this sensitive information may be exposed to attackers.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure CloudWatch logs to monitor image build activities
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS EC2 Image Builder, configure AWS CloudWatch Logs to capture detailed logs of all image build activities. This enables continuous monitoring for unauthorized changes or anomalies in the image-building process.

Enable Logging for Image Builder Pipelines:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the Image Builder service and select the pipelines you wish to monitor.
  • Enable CloudWatch logging for each pipeline to ensure that all build steps, configuration changes, and errors are logged.

Create a CloudWatch Log Group:

  • Create a dedicated CloudWatch Log Group for Image Builder logs to centralize log data for easier management and analysis.
  • Set appropriate retention policies for the log group based on your organizations data retention and compliance requirements.

Set Up Monitoring and Alerts:

  • Use CloudWatch Alarms to create alerts based on specific log patterns or events, such as build failures, unauthorized access attempts, or configuration changes.
  • Configure alerts to notify security teams via email, SMS, or integration with AWS SNS (Simple Notification Service) for real-time incident response.

Review Logs Regularly:

  • Regularly review CloudWatch logs for any unauthorized changes or anomalies in the build process.
  • Implement automated log analysis tools or scripts to detect patterns indicative of malicious activity or configuration drift.

reference.name: Monitor events and logs in Image Builder

customField.value: AU-6 Audit Record Review, Analysis, and Reporting

countermeasure.name: Remove hard-coded sensitive data from build scripts and recipes
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent unauthorized access and data leakage, ensure that build scripts and recipes used in AWS EC2 Image Builder do not contain hard-coded sensitive data, such as credentials or API keys. Additionally, sanitize build outputs to remove any accidental inclusion of sensitive information.

Review and Clean Build Scripts:

  • Inspect all build scripts and recipes for any hard-coded sensitive data, such as usernames, passwords, API keys, or other confidential information.
  • Replace hard-coded sensitive information with environment variables or AWS Secrets Manager references to ensure sensitive data is not directly embedded in scripts.

Use AWS Secrets Manager or Parameter Store:

  • Store sensitive information securely using AWS Secrets Manager or AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Reference these securely stored secrets in your build scripts to avoid exposing them in plain text.
  • Set appropriate access permissions on secrets to ensure only authorized users and services can access them.

Sanitize Build Outputs:

  • Implement steps within your build process to sanitize outputs, such as removing temporary files, clearing environment variables, or scrubbing logs that might contain sensitive information.
  • Use automated scripts or tools to scan build outputs for any residual sensitive data before finalizing the image.

Implement Continuous Security Scanning:

  • Use security scanning tools to automatically check build scripts and outputs for hard-coded secrets or sensitive data. Integrate these scans into your CI/CD pipeline to ensure ongoing compliance.
  • Regularly update scanning tools and rules to detect new types of sensitive information.

reference.name: Security in Image Builder

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to Image Builder resources with IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EC2 Image Builder, configure AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to restrict access to Image Builder resources, ensuring that only authorized users or roles have the necessary permissions.

Define Least Privilege IAM Policies:

  • Create IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege, granting only the minimum permissions required for users or roles to perform their specific tasks in Image Builder.
  • For example, create separate policies for users who only need read access to image pipelines versus those who require full control to create or modify resources.

Assign IAM Roles to Image Builder Resources:

  • Use IAM roles to manage permissions for EC2 instances, pipelines, and other resources used by Image Builder. Assign these roles to resources in a way that limits access to only what is necessary for the build process.
  • Ensure that roles assigned to Image Builder resources are configured with trust policies to prevent unauthorized use.

Regularly Review and Update IAM Policies:

  • Periodically review IAM policies and access permissions to ensure they are up-to-date and reflect current security requirements. Remove or update policies that grant excessive permissions.
  • Conduct regular audits to identify and revoke any unused or overly permissive roles and access keys.

Monitor and Log IAM Access:

  • Enable AWS CloudTrail to log all IAM-related activities and monitor access to Image Builder resources. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or policy changes.
  • Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer to identify resources that are accessible from outside your AWS account and tighten permissions as needed.

reference.name: Image Builder identity-based policies

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Store built images in encrypted and secure storage
countermeasure.desc:
To protect the integrity and confidentiality of AWS EC2 Image Builder outputs, ensure that all built images are stored in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets or other secure, access-controlled storage options.

Enable Encryption for S3 Buckets:

  • When storing built images in Amazon S3, enable server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS KMS-managed keys (SSE-KMS) or S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) to encrypt images at rest.
  • Configure S3 bucket policies to enforce encryption on all uploads, ensuring no unencrypted images are stored.

Implement Strict Access Controls:

  • Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies and S3 bucket policies to restrict access to the buckets storing built images. Grant permissions only to specific users or roles that need access, following the principle of least privilege.
  • Configure S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) to ensure that no public access is allowed unless explicitly required for specific use cases.

Regularly Audit Storage Permissions:

  • Set up regular audits of S3 bucket permissions and access logs using AWS CloudTrail to ensure that access controls are properly configured and no unauthorized access has occurred.
  • Use AWS Config rules to continuously monitor the S3 bucket settings and receive alerts for any deviations from the security baseline.

Use Additional Secure Storage Options:

  • If storing images outside of S3, ensure that the storage service or infrastructure used supports encryption at rest and robust access controls.
  • Implement similar security controls, such as encryption, access control, and logging, to maintain the security of images stored in alternative storage solutions.

reference.name: Security in Image Builder

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use trusted and verified base images for image builds
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security and integrity of images created with AWS EC2 Image Builder, always use trusted and verified base images from reputable sources, such as AWS Marketplace or internally vetted images.

Select Verified Base Images:

  • Choose base images from trusted sources like AWS Marketplace, which provides verified images that are regularly updated and maintained to ensure security and compliance.
  • When using internally vetted images, ensure they have been thoroughly tested and approved by your organizations security team.

Establish a Base Image Approval Process:

  • Implement a formal process for approving base images before they are used in the build process. This process should include security checks, vulnerability scans, and validation against your organizations security standards.
  • Maintain a list of approved base images and update it regularly to ensure that only secure and compliant images are used.

Regularly Update Base Images:

  • Ensure that base images are regularly updated with the latest security patches and updates. Set up automated checks or notifications to stay informed of new image versions or patches available from your trusted sources.
  • Replace outdated or unsupported images in your build pipelines with their updated, secure versions.

Monitor for Image Changes or Compromises:

  • Use AWS services like AWS Config and AWS CloudTrail to monitor for any unauthorized changes or modifications to your base images. Set up alerts for unexpected modifications or access attempts.
  • Regularly audit your image repository to detect any signs of compromise or unauthorized images being used.

reference.name: Security in Image Builder

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Image Builder components
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Unauthorized access to AWS EC2 Image Builder components, such as pipelines, recipes, and distribution settings, can allow attackers to modify images, insert malicious code, or disrupt the image creation process, compromising the security of deployed instances.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised accounts.
  • Vectors:
    • Weak or misconfigured IAM policies granting broad access.
    • Compromised credentials or roles with Image Builder access.
    • Inadequate access controls on AWS resources.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Compromised images containing vulnerabilities or malware.
  • Operational Disruption: Disruption of image-building pipelines and deployment processes.
  • Data Leakage: Exposure of sensitive information within image configurations.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust due to deployment of insecure instances.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Compromised IAM Role: An attacker uses a compromised IAM role with broad permissions to insert a backdoor into an image recipe, leading to compromised instances.
  • Misconfigured Public Access: Public access to pipelines is mistakenly allowed, enabling a malicious insider to use outdated base images with known vulnerabilities.
  • Insider Manipulation: An employee alters distribution settings to leak images to unauthorized regions or accounts, risking exposure of proprietary data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in built images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Exposure of sensitive data in built images occurs when credentials, API keys, or other sensitive information are unintentionally included in images during the AWS EC2 Image Builder process. This can lead to unauthorized access and misuse of the exposed data, compromising security and privacy.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Hard-coded sensitive data within image build scripts or configuration files.
    • Insufficient sanitization of build artifacts or logs containing sensitive information.
    • Use of unprotected environment variables or files during the build process.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to credentials or sensitive information, potentially leading to further breaches.
  • Service Compromise: Exposure of API keys or credentials could allow attackers to access or manipulate AWS resources.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of regulatory requirements due to inadequate protection of sensitive data.
  • Financial Loss: Potential costs associated with incident response, fines, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Hard-Coded Credentials in Build Scripts: An engineer includes database credentials in a build script for convenience. These credentials are inadvertently baked into the final image, allowing attackers to access the database when the image is deployed.
  • Unprotected Environment Variables: Sensitive information is stored in environment variables used during the image-building process. If these variables are not properly sanitized, they could be exposed in the built image or build logs.
  • Insufficient Data Sanitization: An outdated build script inadvertently copies a configuration file containing sensitive customer data into the final image, resulting in data exposure when the image is deployed.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure storage of built images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Insecure storage of built images in AWS EC2 Image Builder can expose images to unauthorized access, modification, or tampering. If built images are stored in unsecured locations, such as unencrypted S3 buckets or improperly configured storage services, they can be accessed by malicious actors, potentially leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious instances.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Storing built images in unencrypted S3 buckets or other storage locations.
    • Misconfigured bucket policies or ACLs that allow public or unauthorized access.
    • Lack of access controls, allowing unrestricted access to image storage locations.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Malicious actors can access or download built images, potentially exposing sensitive configurations or embedded data.
  • Image Tampering: Attackers may modify stored images to include malicious code or backdoors.
  • Compliance Violations: Storing sensitive images without proper encryption or access controls may breach regulatory requirements.
  • Deployment of Compromised Instances: Deployment of tampered or malicious images could compromise application and infrastructure security.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Unencrypted Image Storage: Built images are stored in an S3 bucket without encryption. A cybercriminal gains access to the bucket and downloads the images, analyzing them for vulnerabilities or sensitive information.
  • Publicly Accessible S3 Bucket: An administrator misconfigures an S3 bucket policy, making it publicly accessible. An attacker discovers the misconfiguration and modifies the images to include a backdoor before they are deployed.
  • Improper Access Controls: An insider with excessive access permissions deletes critical images or replaces them with unauthorized versions, leading to deployment issues and potential security breaches.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring and logging for image builds
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Monitoring and Logging for Image Builds" refers to the absence of adequate monitoring and logging mechanisms for AWS EC2 Image Builder processes. Without detailed logging and monitoring, unauthorized changes, malicious activities, or failures in the image-building pipeline may go undetected, compromising the security and integrity of the resulting images.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors:
    • Lack of detailed logs capturing the build process, changes, or errors.
    • Insufficient monitoring of build pipeline activities, leading to undetected unauthorized modifications.
    • No alerts or notifications set up for failed or suspicious build activities.

Impacts:

  • Undetected Security Incidents: Malicious changes or unauthorized access may go unnoticed, resulting in compromised images.
  • Operational Inefficiencies: Failures or issues in the build process may not be identified promptly, delaying deployments and updates.
  • Compliance Violations: Failing to log and monitor critical activities can lead to non-compliance with security policies and regulations.
  • Image Integrity Compromise: Lack of monitoring may allow corrupted or compromised images to be deployed, posing risks to application and infrastructure security.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Undetected Malicious Changes: An insider with access to Image Builder components alters a build script to include malicious code. Without detailed logging or monitoring, this unauthorized change goes unnoticed, resulting in compromised images being deployed.
  • Missed Build Failures: An external attacker exploits a vulnerability in a base image, causing the build process to fail intermittently. Due to a lack of monitoring, these failures are not detected, delaying response and remediation efforts.
  • Unauthorized Access Remains Unnoticed: A compromised IAM user accesses Image Builder components and makes unauthorized changes to the distribution settings. Without proper logging and monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the compromised images are deployed.

threat.name: Use of untrusted source images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

The "Use of Untrusted Source Images" threat occurs when AWS EC2 Image Builder uses base images that are not verified or come from unreliable sources. This can introduce vulnerabilities, malware, or backdoors into the built images, posing significant security risks to the entire environment where these images are deployed.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Utilizing base images from unverified or third-party repositories with unknown security practices.
    • Incorporating images that have been compromised or contain outdated software with known vulnerabilities.
    • Lack of proper vetting processes for sourcing and updating base images.

Impacts:

  • Security Compromise: Deployment of images built from untrusted sources may introduce malware or unauthorized access points.
  • Data Breach: Compromised images could allow attackers to exfiltrate sensitive data or access other resources.
  • Operational Disruption: Vulnerable or malicious images could lead to service outages, degraded performance, or loss of control over systems.
  • Compliance Violations: Using unverified images could lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements or internal security policies.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Deployment of Compromised Image: A base image from an unverified third-party source is used in the build process. The image contains hidden malware that activates upon deployment, providing attackers with unauthorized access to the network.
  • Outdated Image with Known Vulnerabilities: An image is sourced from an external repository without verification and contains outdated software with known vulnerabilities. Attackers exploit these vulnerabilities to gain access to critical systems after the image is deployed.
  • Malicious Insider Incident: An insider with access to the Image Builder pipeline replaces a trusted base image with a tampered version from an untrusted source. This modified image includes a backdoor that is later used to gain unauthorized access to the deployed environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1183 - Image File Execution Options Injection

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineregular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable Amazon S3 server access logging
countermeasure.desc:
Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests that are made to a bucket. Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

1.13 - Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less
1.16 - Ensure a support role has been created to manage incidents with AWS Support
1.17 - Ensure IAM instance roles are used for AWS resource access from instances

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.
