usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: SingleAZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicescausing complete service disruption.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZspecific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backend jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timesensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossAZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZA; all Lambda functions in that singleAZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCbound Lambdas cant reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZB; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplychain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Python2.7 is targeted with a known bufferoverflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Java8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryleak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryoften using wildcards for actions or resourcesexposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overpermissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastprivilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stoleneither through code, environment variables, or execution contextallowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdparty library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataendpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherprivilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardcoded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functions IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationssuch as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securitygroup restrictionsthey gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdparty dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openredirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackercontrolled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functions network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backend systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on port3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackers external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions cant be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposehindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdparty tooling that doesnt enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams cant quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagbased IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked orphan functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsescaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated services Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arent owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationsuch as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsis stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdparty service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardcoded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionssuch as API Gateway requests, servicetoservice calls, or event payloadsis sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, maninthemiddle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that dont enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Intransit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functions URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnt require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functions execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdparty accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourcebased policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossaccount policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highvolume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. CrossAccount Abuse: A partners account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentprocessing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arent captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logdelivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arent noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cant be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditlogging mandates (e.g., PCIDSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentprocessing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesvia compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersinjects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplychain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functions IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseshell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataexfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdparty layer bundles a cryptominer, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

Attack on back-end server stops it functioning
weakness.desc: For example it prevents it from interacting with vehicles and providing services they rely on

countermeasure.desc: Through system design and access control it should not be possible for unauthorized personnel to access personal or system critical data

threat.name: Back-end servers used as a means to attack a vehicle or extract data
threat.desc:
This threat include:
  • Back-end servers as an attack vector

threat.name: Services from back-end server being disrupted affecting the operation of a vehicle

This threat include:
  • Disruption of services from back-end

threat.name: Vehicle related data held on back-end servers being lost or compromised
threat.desc:
This threat include:
  • Loss of back-end servers's vehicle related data

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Heres a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

standard.ref: AC-14 PERMITTED ACTIONS WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION OR AUTHENTICATION
AC-19 Access Control for Mobile Devices
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(2)
SC-2 Separation of System and User Functionality

countermeasure.name: Implement secure session management
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the "User Profile" software component through secure session management, follow these targeted, actionable steps. Secure session management is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and protect user data. This guidance focuses on creating and managing sessions securely, with an emphasis on web applications.

Step 1: Generate Secure Session Identifiers

  1. Use Secure, Random Values: Ensure session identifiers (IDs) are generated using a cryptographically secure random number generator.
  2. Maintain Sufficient Length: Session IDs should be long enough to prevent brute force attacks. Aim for at least 128 bits of entropy.

Step 2: Use HTTPS for All Transactions

  1. Implement HTTPS: Ensure that all communication between the client and server is encrypted using HTTPS to protect the session ID and other sensitive data in transit.
  2. Secure Cookies: Set the Secure attribute on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over encrypted connections.

Step 3: Proper Session Expiration

  1. Set Timeout Limits: Implement automatic session expiration. Sessions should time out after a predefined period of inactivity (e.g., 15 to 30 minutes).
  2. Clear Session at Logout: Ensure that sessions are completely invalidated and cleared from the server upon user logout.

Step 4: Implement Cookie Attributes Correctly

  1. HttpOnly Attribute: Set the HttpOnly attribute for cookies to prevent access to the session cookie via client-side scripts, mitigating the risk of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
  2. SameSite Attribute: Use the SameSite attribute to restrict how cookies are sent with cross-site requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Step 5: Validate Session ID for Every Request

  1. Verify Sessions: Check the validity of the session ID for every request to ensure it matches the user and hasn't been tampered with.
  2. Regenerate Session IDs: Upon login, logout, and during regular intervals, regenerate session IDs to mitigate session fixation attacks.

Step 6: Store Sessions Securely

  1. Use Server-Side Storage: Preferably store session data on the server side where possible, using a secure and scalable session management system.
  2. Encrypt Sensitive Data: If any sensitive information must be stored within the session, ensure it is encrypted.

Good Security Practices

  • Monitor and Log Session Activities: Implement monitoring to detect unusual session patterns or behaviors that may indicate an attack.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection: Sanitize user input and implement content security policies to prevent XSS attacks, which can compromise session security.
  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection: Use anti-CSRF tokens in forms and requests to ensure that state-changing requests originate from your application.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on session management to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities.

By following these steps, developers can significantly enhance the security of user sessions within their applications, protecting both user data and the integrity of the application itself.

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
When developing software, particularly components like user profiles that accept user-generated input, its crucial to mitigate the risk of injection attacks. Injection attacks occur when attackers input malicious data that the system interprets and executes as commands. This can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and system compromise. To prevent such vulnerabilities, follow these steps to sanitize inputs effectively:

Validate Input Strictly:

  • Enforce strict type, length, and format for all inputs. Use regular expressions to validate string inputs against expected patterns.
  • Implement client-side validation for immediate feedback but always perform server-side validation as the primary defense mechanism.

Employ Parameterized Queries:

  • Use parameterized queries or prepared statements for database access. This ensures that input is treated only as data and not executable code, effectively neutralizing SQL injection threats.

Utilize Content Security Policy (CSP):

  • Implement a Content Security Policy as an additional layer of protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP can restrict how and where content can be loaded, preventing the execution of unauthorized scripts.

Encode Data:

  • Before displaying user input on web pages or in application interfaces, encode the data to escape any characters that could be interpreted as executable code. This is especially crucial for HTML, JavaScript, and SQL outputs.

Leverage Security Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Take advantage of existing security libraries and frameworks that offer input sanitization and validation functions. These are often well-tested and updated to defend against emerging threats.

Conduct Regular Security Audits:

  • Regularly review and audit your codebase and dependencies for vulnerabilities. Automated security scanning tools can identify potential injection flaws in your application.

Educate and Train Developers:

  • Ensure that all team members are aware of the risks associated with injection attacks and understand the importance of input sanitization. Promote a culture of security within the development team.

Test for Vulnerabilities:

  • Implement comprehensive testing strategies, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing, to uncover and mitigate injection vulnerabilities.

By adhering to these guidelines and adopting a proactive security posture, developers can significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks on user profile components and other vulnerable parts of their applications. Always stay informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities to maintain the robustness of your security measures.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposed sensitive data refers to personal or confidential information that becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals due to inadequate protection measures. In the context of a User Profile component, this could include names, email addresses, passwords, payment information, or any personal data that users submit. Exposure can occur through various means, such as improper access controls, lack of encryption, or inadvertent leaks via logs or error messages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Includes cybercriminals aiming for identity theft or financial gain, competitors seeking confidential information, and insiders with malicious intent or negligence.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Attackers manipulate direct references to access other users' data.
    • Insufficient Data Encryption: Data transmitted or stored without encryption can be intercepted or accessed.
    • Misconfigured Databases or Servers: Incorrect configurations can expose data through unintended public access points.
    • Caching Mechanisms: Sensitive information stored in cache without proper access controls could be leaked.

Impacts

  • Identity Theft: Exposed personal details can lead to identity theft, significantly impacting users' lives.
  • Financial Loss: Exposure of payment information can lead to unauthorized transactions and financial losses for users.
  • Reputation Damage: Organizations responsible for data breaches face severe reputational damage, eroding trust among users and partners.
  • Legal and Compliance Violations: Breaches involving sensitive data can result in legal penalties, fines, and failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. IDOR Exploit: An attacker discovers that the user profile edit function is vulnerable to IDOR. By changing the user ID in the URL, they gain access to and modify other users' profiles, harvesting sensitive data.
  2. Database Misconfiguration: A database containing user profiles is mistakenly configured to allow public access. Sensitive user data is indexed by search engines, making it easily accessible to anyone performing a simple search.
  3. Insecure API Endpoint: An API endpoint designed to fetch user profile details does not properly verify the requestor's identity or permissions. Attackers exploit this by crafting requests that retrieve personal information of all users.
  4. Error Message Leakage: A coding error in the user profile management system leads to detailed error messages being displayed, including sensitive database information. Attackers use this information to further exploit the system.

To mitigate the risk of exposed sensitive data:

  • Implement Strict Access Controls: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can access or modify user profile data.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Use strong encryption for storing and transmitting user data.
  • Regularly Audit and Configure Security Settings: Regularly review and update configurations for databases, servers, and applications to prevent accidental exposure.
  • Data Minimization: Collect and retain only the minimum necessary personal information for users.
  • Error Handling: Implement secure error handling practices that do not expose sensitive information in logs or error messages.
  • Educate Employees: Provide training on data protection best practices and the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

By addressing these aspects, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with the exposure of sensitive data within user profile components.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in access control systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control systems are designed to restrict unauthorized users from performing certain actions within a software system, typically through mechanisms like authentication and authorization. Flaws in these systems can arise from misconfigurations, software vulnerabilities, or inadequate security policies, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security measures. This can lead to unauthorized access to or manipulation of user profiles and associated data, which may contain sensitive personal information, preferences, and security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents include:

  1. Cybercriminals: Seeking financial gain through data theft, fraud, or selling access.
  2. Disgruntled Employees: Internal actors who exploit their knowledge of the system's weaknesses.
  3. Competitors: Looking to gain a competitive edge by stealing confidential data.
  4. Hacktivists or State-Sponsored Actors: Targeting systems for political, ideological, or strategic reasons.

Attack Vectors involve:

  1. Privilege Escalation: Exploiting vulnerabilities to gain elevated access rights.
  2. Authorization Bypass: Manipulating the system to access functions or data without proper authorization.
  3. Credential Stuffing: Using breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access.
  4. Session Hijacking: Exploiting flaws in session management to take over a user's legitimate session.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Unauthorized access to user profiles can lead to the exposure of sensitive personal and financial information.
  2. Identity Theft: Attackers can use stolen data for impersonation and fraud.
  3. Loss of Integrity: Modification of user data can lead to incorrect or malicious actions being taken on behalf of the user.
  4. Reputational Damage: Breaches can severely damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust and customers.
  5. Regulatory and Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in fines and legal action.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizations reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

weakness.name: CWE-116
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-116: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-288
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-288: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel A product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-345
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: CWE-706
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-706: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt stored tokens and implement token rotation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of OAuth tokens on the MCP Server, it is essential to protect them with encryption when stored and ensure their limited lifespan by periodically rotating them. The following steps outline the process required to implement these measures:

  1. Choose a Strong Encryption Algorithm: Adopt Advanced Encryption Standard with a 256-bit key (AES-256) for encrypting OAuth tokens at rest. This algorithm is widely regarded for its robustness and efficiency, providing a high level of security.

  2. Implement Token Encryption: Utilize a cryptographic library compatible with AES-256 to encrypt the tokens before storage.

    • Ensure that the encryption process is performed whenever a token is created or updated.
    • Store the encrypted token securely in the database while keeping the encryption keys protected using a key management service or hardware security module.

  3. Set Short-lived Token Expiry: Configure the OAuth tokens to have a short lifespan (e.g., minutes or hours), depending on the application's specific requirements.

    • Implement mechanisms that automatically revoke or refresh the tokens when their expiry is reached, warning both the server and client beforehand.

  4. Enable Token Rotation: Regularly rotate tokens to limit the impact of any potential token theft. Implement a scheduled process that generates new tokens at predefined intervals (e.g., periodically or upon every access).

    • Ensure that the rotation process maintains session integrity by validating the presence of updated tokens before invalidating the existing ones.
    • Communicate the new tokens securely to the client applications while invalidating the old ones to prevent misuse.

  5. Audit and Monitor: Set up logging mechanisms to monitor token usage, detect anomalies, and track misuse patterns.

    • Use this data to trigger alerts and establish security incident response plans to act promptly on potential threats.

References

  • Model Context Protocol (MCP) vs Security

countermeasure.name: Enforce end-to-end encryption and integrity verification
countermeasure.desc:
To secure the MCP Server by requiring TLS 1.3 with strong cipher suites and using digital signatures for ensuring data integrity, follow these detailed steps:

Step 1: Enabling and Configuring TLS 1.3

  1. Update Server Software: Ensure that your server software or application environment (e.g., Apache, Nginx) is updated to the latest version that supports TLS 1.3. Older versions may only support TLS 1.2 or earlier, which have known vulnerabilities.
  2. Configure TLS 1.3: Modify the servers configuration file to specifically enable TLS 1.3. For an Nginx server, this might involve editing the nginx.conf file: 
    ssl_protocols TLSv1.3;
  3. Select Strong Cipher Suites: Configure your server to use strong, recommended cipher suites. For TLS 1.3, the cipher suite selection is simplified. Ensure that you have removed weaker cipher suites from your TLS 1.2 configuration if used concurrently.

Step 2: Implementing Digital Signatures

  1. Establish Digital Signature Strategy: Determine which digital signature methods (e.g., HMAC, ECDSA) suit your needs based on the environment's computing resources and desired level of security. ECDSA typically offers efficient and robust security.
  2. Enable and Configure HMAC: If opting to use HMAC, ensure that your application supports enabling HMAC with an adequate hash function (such as SHA-256 or SHA-384). For instance, in a codebase configuration, include: 
    HMAC_SHA256(key, data);
  3. Implement ECDSA: If selecting ECDSA, ensure that your cryptographic library is current and supports ECDSA. Registration and management of key pairs are critical:
    • Generate an ECDSA key pair (private/public) using tools like OpenSSL.
    • Implement routines to sign data and verify signatures:
      • ECDSA_sign, ECDSA_verify;
  4. Integrate Signature Verification: Incorporate signature verification at the receiving server-side to validate data integrity. This involves adding appropriate code logic to ensure that payloads are verified upon receipt.

Step 3: Testing and Validation

  1. Test the Configuration: Utilize tools like SSL Labs to test and verify the server's TLS configuration. Metrics such as protocol invocation and cipher suite preference should be thoroughly validated to meet the desired security level.
  2. Validate Digital Signatures: Conduct extensive testing of the digital signature process to ensure no data integrity issues during data transmission. Automated tests can affirm the correctness and robustness of signature operations.

Step 4: Maintenance and Monitoring

  1. Regularly Update Software: Keep abreast of security advisories related to TLS and cryptographic libraries to maintain resilience against newly discovered vulnerabilities.
  2. Monitor Logs: Implement logging mechanisms that alert administrators to any failed TLS negotiations or signature verifications, to address potential threats swiftly.

References

  • Model Context Protocol Security Considerations

countermeasure.name: Harden server security and apply token vaulting
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of MCP servers, start by deploying a hardened operating system. A hardened OS is customized to reduce its vulnerability to attacks by minimizing unnecessary services, ports, and potentially exploitable software. Choose a Linux distribution designed for security, such as Ubuntu Server in its Minimal Installation form, or use security-enhanced versions like SELinux or AppArmor.

  1. Install the OS: During installation, select minimal configurations that exclude non-essential services. Use a package manager to remove any redundant software and dependencies.
  2. Configure File Permissions: Ensure that only necessary processes and users have access to critical system files. Utilize tools like 'chmod' and 'chown' to adjust file permissions and ownership appropriately.
  3. Enable SELinux or AppArmor: Configure SELinux or AppArmor to enforce strict access controls at the kernel level. Set these policies to enforcement mode rather than permissive to ensure maximum security efficacy.

Next, limit network exposure by deploying firewalls around the MCP servers. This involves configuring both software firewalls on the server and hardware firewalls at the network perimeter.

  1. Install and Configure Software Firewall: Utilize iptables or a similar firewall solution to control incoming and outgoing traffic based on predefined security rules. Define specific rules that block all traffic except for those needed by the MCP server operations (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS on specific ports).
  2. Setup Hardware Firewall: Implement network-level firewalls at the perimeter of the enterprise network, ensuring they are configured to inspect and filter traffic to the MCP servers specifically. Use these to prevent unauthorized access and detect potential threats early.

Token storage requires particular attention to ensure that sensitive tokens are isolated and protected against unauthorized access.

  1. Deploy a Token Vault: Set up isolated, hardened vault services such as HashiCorp Vault for token storage. This should be configured to operate on a different server from the MCP server to decrease the attack surface.
  2. Configure Vault Policies: Define strict access policies within the vault to determine who or what can retrieve tokens. Utilize role-based access controls (RBAC) to enforce these restrictions.
  3. Enable Auditing: Configure detailed logging within the vault to capture all access attempts to the stored tokens. Monitor and respond to the audit logs for any suspicious activities.

References

  • Overview of MCP Server Security Measures

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and context validation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP Server against resource exhaustion attacks, follow these implementation steps:

Step-by-Step Guidance

  1. Implement API Gateway Rate Limiting:
    1. Select an appropriate API gateway solution that supports rate limiting. Options include AWS API Gateway, Kong, or NGINX.
    2. Define rate limiting policies based on your application's typical usage patterns. Consider factors such as the maximum number of requests per minute/hour and user roles.
    3. Configure rate limiting rules within the API gateway:
      • Create rules to limit the number of requests per IP address per given time frame.
      • Set different thresholds for different types of users (e.g., authenticated vs. unauthenticated).
    4. Test the rate limiting configuration in a staging environment to ensure that legitimate traffic is not being inadvertently blocked.
  2. Validate Incoming Context Payloads:
    1. Define acceptable payload size limits based on your application's needs and the average size of expected requests.
    2. Implement input validation on incoming requests:
      • Checking the size of incoming payloads to ensure it does not exceed the predefined limit.
      • Verifying the structure of the payload to match expected schemas or formats.
    3. Use libraries or frameworks that support schema validation to simplify this process. Options include JSON Schema for JSON payloads.
    4. Regularly update validation rules to adapt to new threats and ensure comprehensive coverage.
  3. Monitoring and Logging:
    1. Ensure that the API gateway logs rate limiting events for analysis and tuning of thresholds.
    2. Set up alerts to notify administrators of any unusual or excessive request patterns.
    3. Analyze logs regularly to refine rate limits and validation rules.
  4. Documentation and Training:
    1. Document the implemented rate limiting and validation strategies.
    2. Conduct training sessions for developers and system administrators on the importance and practices of API security.

References

  • The Security Risks of Model Context Protocol (MCP)

countermeasure.name: Implement role-based access control with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP server by configuring strict Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), follow these steps:

  1. Review Existing Roles and Permissions:
    • Access the MCP server's current configuration of roles and permissions.
    • Document all existing roles, ensuring clarity on what each role is intended to perform.
    • Identify permissions granted to each role and cross-reference with their necessity for performing assigned tasks.
  2. Define and Assign Minimal Roles:
    • Create a comprehensive list of tasks that need to be performed by users and services interacting with the MCP server.
    • Design roles around these tasks, ensuring minimal overlap and role-specific permissions.
    • Assign these newly defined roles to users and services according to their functional requirements.
  3. Implement Principle of Least Privilege:
    • Ensure each role has only the permissions necessary to perform their associated tasks.
    • Remove any superfluous permissions or conglomerated roles not aligned with the Principle of Least Privilege (PoLP).
  4. Configure and Test RBAC Policies:
    • Access the configuration settings for the MCP server and apply the newly defined roles and permissions.
    • Conduct thorough testing to verify that each role can perform necessary functions without bypassing security restrictions.
    • Engage in penetration testing or simulation of attacks to ensure that no unauthorized access is possible under the new configuration.
  5. Audit and Monitor Roles and Access:
    • Set up logging to monitor role assignments and access patterns continuously.
    • Perform regular audits to ensure that the roles and permissions align with organizational needs and adjust them as necessary.
  6. Educate and Train Users:
    • Conduct training for users and administrators to help them understand the importance of RBAC and their responsibilities.
    • Provide documentation and resources that detail how to work within the RBAC policies as defined.
  7. Maintain and Update RBAC Configuration:
    • Regularly review and update RBAC settings as new services are added or removed, or as organizational requirements evolve.
    • Respond promptly to any breaches or instances where access control polices fail by refining policies to cover any identified gaps.

Implementing these strategies ensures robust security by deploying a well-structured RBAC configuration that limits access strictly based on necessity.

References

  • MCP Server Development Guide

countermeasure.name: Implement strong client authentication
countermeasure.desc:
1. Install and Configure the Required Software:
    • Ensure that your MCP server and client systems have a compatible version of OpenSSL or a similar library that supports mutual TLS (mTLS).
    • Ensure that your server software (such as Apache, Nginx, or any MCP-specific server) supports mTLS. You may need to install or enable additional modules for your server.
  2. Generate Server and Client Certificates:
    • Create a Certificate Authority (CA) if you don't already have one. This CA will be used to sign the server and client certificates.
    • Generate a private key and a certificate signing request (CSR) for the server. Submit the CSR to your CA to obtain the server certificate.
    • Repeat the above step for each client that needs to connect to the MCP server, ensuring that each client has a unique certificate signed by your CA.
  3. Configure the MCP Server for mTLS:
    • Edit the server configuration file to enable TLS. This typically involves specifying the path to the server's private key and certificate, and the CA's certificate that can validate client certificates.
    • Enable client certificate verification. In Apache, for example, this can be done by setting SSLVerifyClient require and specifying the verification depth.
    • Configure the list of trusted CAs that the server should use to verify client certificates. It should include the CA that signed your client certificates.
  4. Client Configuration:
    • Ensure each client is configured to use its own private key and certificate when connecting to the MCP server. The client must also trust the server's certificate, typically by including the server's CA certificate.
    • Update your client software's configuration files to enable mTLS during connections. This often involves specifying the path to the client's certificate and private key.
  5. Testing and Validation:
    • Test the connection between your clients and the MCP server to ensure that mTLS is functioning correctly. The server should reject any client connections that do not present a valid certificate.
    • Review server logs to verify successful and failed authentication attempts. Logs can help diagnose issues related to certificate validation.
  6. Ongoing Management:
    • Regularly audit and rotate client certificates to reduce the risk of credential compromise.
    • Monitor for any unsupported or deprecated TLS versions and ciphers in your server configuration to maintain strong encryption standards.

References

  • Model Context Protocol Security Considerations

countermeasure.name: Output filtering and LLM containment
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that any output generated by the LLM in response to tool schemas, context inputs, or user queries is thoroughly inspected before it is returned to the calling system or user. This countermeasure protects against information disclosure, prompt injection amplification, data leakage, and the unintended execution of harmful content by downstream systems.

1. Enforce output sanitization and redaction policies

  • Implement a post-generation policy engine that inspects every LLM response.
    • Sanitize outputs by escaping or removing risky content (e.g., embedded shell commands, secrets, tokens).
    • Redact matches against known sensitive patterns (e.g., private key headers, AWS keys, email addresses).
    • Normalize outputs to remove encoding tricks (e.g., base64 in HTML, Unicode obfuscation).

2. Apply token-level scanning and pattern matching

  • Use regular expressions or token classifiers to detect:
    • Sensitive identifiers (e.g., PRIVATE KEY, Authorization: Bearer, token=...)
    • Dangerous language (e.g., rm -rf, wget http://, exec()
    • Leakage of system metadata (e.g., file paths, usernames, .env variables)
  • Consider implementing allowlists and blocklists based on project-specific sensitivity thresholds.

3. Define and enforce output boundaries

  • Set character count or token limits on outputs.
  • Truncate overly long completions or responses that exceed expected formats.
  • Disallow or flag unexpected structures (e.g., full file dumps, multiline code blocks) where inappropriate.

4. Implement configurable LLM containment modes

  • Provide configurable response enforcement levels:
    • Passive: Log violations but allow the response.
    • Active: Redact or replace matched content.
    • Strict: Reject and regenerate the response or return an error.
  • Tie enforcement level to the trust level of the request context (e.g., tool source, LLM prompt origin, or user session).

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1054 - Software Configuration||ATLAS - AML.M0002 - Passive AI Output Obfuscation

countermeasure.name: Request minimal permission scopes and monitor token usage
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively implement a least privilege model when dealing with OAuth scopes on the MCP Server, adhere to the following guidelines:

  1. Inventory OAuth Scopes:

    Start by listing all the OAuth scopes currently used by the MCP Server. Categorize these based on the services they access and evaluate their necessity. This provides a foundational understanding necessary before implementing a least privilege model.

  2. Determine Scope Requirements:

    For each application or service consuming your API, determine the minimal set of OAuth scopes required to function correctly. Avoid configuring scopes that provide full service access unless there is a specific justification.

  3. Update OAuth Configurations:

    Modify OAuth configurations to ensure that only essential scopes are requested. This can be done through your identity providers interface by tailoring OAuth client settings to the least privilege required. Validate these settings by performing integration tests to confirm that operations continue successfully with the reduced scopes.

  4. Monitor API Usage:

    Implement a logging mechanism to continuously monitor API requests and their corresponding OAuth scopes usage. Use tools such as API gateways or log aggregators to analyze this data. Monitor for patterns such as unusual access times, frequency of access, or unexpected scope usage, which could indicate potential anomalies.

  5. Review and Adjust Periodically:

    Regularly review the OAuth scope configurations and usage logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege model. Conduct periodic audits to assess whether the current scopes are still relevant and appropriately scoped based on evolving business requirements.

Implementing these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your MCP Server by reducing the attack surface associated with OAuth scopes.

References

  • What is MCP in AI? Everything You Wanted to Ask!

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1038 - Execution Prevention||ATLAS - AML.M0004 - Restrict Number of AI Model Queries

countermeasure.name: Sanitize AI inputs and validate user intent before execution
countermeasure.desc:
1. Analyze and Identify High-Risk Actions: Begin by reviewing all AI-driven requests and their interactions with the MCP server. Identify commands or actions that have significant operational, financial, or security implications. List these high-risk actions to target in the validation and confirmation process.
  2. Implement Strict Input Validation:
    • Use whitelisting techniques to allow only pre-approved inputs and commands. This restricts the input space to safe commands.
    • Set up character restrictions, ensuring that inputs follow expected data types, lengths, and patterns such as using regex for format validation.
    • Employ sanitization routines to remove any malicious scripts or code that might be injected through AI-driven requests. Make sure to escape input to prevent XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) and other injection attacks.
  3. Integrate Confirmation Dialogs:
    • Design dialogs that prompt confirmation for actions deemed high-risk. Ensure these dialogs clearly present the consequence of executing the action and require explicit user acknowledgment before proceeding.
    • For sensitive operations, implement a dual-confirmation mechanism where a secondary validation or authorization is required from a different user or system administrator.
  4. Utilize AI-Based Anomaly Detection:
    • Incorporate AI models to monitor normal behavior patterns and flag unusual or out-of-pattern requests. This proactive monitoring helps detect potential malicious actions sparked by compromised AI interactions.
    • Set thresholds and alerts for detected anomalies that require immediate administrative attention and manual inspection.
  5. Testing and Validation:
    • Conduct thorough testing to ensure that the input validation and confirmation dialogs are functioning correctly. Utilize test scenarios to simulate both regular and malicious AI-driven requests.
    • Validate that legitimate operations are not inadvertently blocked and that all flagged actions receive the necessary confirmation before execution.
  6. Update and Maintain:
    • Regularly update the validation logic to incorporate new threat intelligence and adjust the confirmation processes as needed.
    • Conduct periodic reviews and audits of the MCP server's interaction logs to refine security protocols and ensure ongoing compliance with the latest security practices.

References

  • AI Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Security

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance||ATLAS - AML.M0015 - Adversarial Input Detection

countermeasure.name: Trusted schema enforcement
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that the MCP server accepts, stores, and serves only tool schemas that have been thoroughly validated, signed, and protected from unauthorized modification. This involves implementing secure schema ingestion, integrity enforcement, and lifecycle control mechanisms.

1. Comprehensive schema validation (on ingestion)

  • Validate each incoming tool schema against a strict, server-side JSON Schema specification that defines:
    • Allowed fields (e.g., description, parameters, required, default, enum)
    • Data types, formats, min/max constraints, and required fields
    • Rejection of unknown or unsupported fields (e.g., x-malicious)
  • Reject schemas that:
    • Use ambiguous or over-permissive structures (e.g., type: any)
    • Contain embedded code, secrets, or suspicious default values
  • Implement schema validation as a mandatory check before persisting the schema to any backend store.

2. Enforce immutability of trusted schemas

  • Once a schema is accepted and marked as trusted or approved, lock it:
    • Prevent any future overwrites or edits through normal API workflows.
    • Require versioning: modifications must result in a new version (e.g., v2) with a different immutable ID.
  • Log every version and store a hash (e.g., SHA-256) of each version for later integrity checks.

3. Verify digital signatures

  • Require schema submissions to include a detached or embedded digital signature, signed using a known tool provider's private key.
  • Validate the signature using the public key registered for that tool provider:
    • Reject schemas with missing or invalid signatures.
    • Support revocation/rotation of public keys via a key registry or trust store.
  • Protect against replay attacks by associating signed schemas with unique, non-reusable identifiers or timestamps.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program||ATLAS - AML.M0014 - Verify AI Artifacts

countermeasure.name: Unique tool identification and naming validation
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent tool shadowing, typosquatting, and spoofing attacks by ensuring that each tool registered on the MCP server has a verifiable, globally unique identity, and that naming conventions are enforced consistently to block lookalike or ambiguous identifiers.

1. Enforce globally unique tool identifiers

  • Assign or require submission of a globally unique identifier (GUID or UUID) for every tool registered on the MCP server.
    • This identifier should be independent of the human-readable tool name.
    • Use it as the primary reference for routing, versioning, and lookup.
  • Store the GUID in a canonical registry, and reject attempts to re-register the same GUID from unauthorized sources.

2. Apply strict naming policies

  • Define a tool naming policy that:
    • Disallows ambiguous names (e.g., visually similar characters like l, 1, or I).
    • Prevents reuse of names across different tool owners.
    • Prohibits Unicode homoglyphs or encoding tricks that could obfuscate intent.
  • Enforce minimum and maximum lengths, character set restrictions, and optionally namespacing (e.g., org/tool-name) to reduce collisions.

3. Authenticate tool ownership during registration

  • Require MCP tool providers to authenticate when registering or updating tools.
    • Use API keys, OAuth client credentials, or signed metadata headers.
  • Ensure that each tool name or GUID is bound to a specific authenticated identity or organization.

4. Detect and reject duplicates and lookalikes

  • Implement a fuzzy matching or similarity check (e.g., Levenshtein distance) to detect names that are visually or semantically similar to existing tools.
  • Flag suspicious tool names for manual review, especially if they closely resemble well-known or existing tool identifiers.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies
