usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: API Denial of Service (DoS)
threat.desc:
General threat description: Denial of Service (DoS) attacks aim to make the ELB API unavailable by overwhelming it with excessive requests or exploiting resource-intensive vulnerabilities.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Attackers may use botnets, exploit network vulnerabilities, or launch volumetric attacks to consume the ELB system's resources.

Impacts: DoS attacks can cause service outages, disrupt business operations, lead to financial losses, and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a botnet to flood the ELB API with requests, exhausting its resources and causing it to crash.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the ELB API to trigger resource-intensive operations, leading to a denial of service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Misconfiguration of ELB security settings
threat.desc:
General threat description: Misconfiguration of ELB security settings can expose the system to various threats, including unauthorized access, data breaches, and service disruptions. Common misconfigurations include weak access controls, inadequate encryption settings, and improper firewall rules.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Attackers can exploit misconfigurations through network scans, automated tools, or by leveraging default credentials and open ports.

Impacts: Misconfiguration can lead to unauthorized access, data loss, compromised integrity, and potential service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker gains access to the ELB system through an open port that should have been restricted.
  • Sensitive data is transmitted in plaintext due to lack of encryption, allowing attackers to intercept and read the data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception during API communication
threat.desc:
General threat description: Data interception occurs when an attacker eavesdrops on the communication between clients and the ELB API, potentially capturing sensitive information transmitted over the network.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include network-based attackers who use packet sniffing tools to intercept unencrypted data.

Impacts: Data interception can lead to data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a packet sniffer to capture unencrypted data transmitted between the ELB API and clients.
  • Man-in-the-middle attacks where the attacker intercepts and potentially alters the communication between clients and the ELB API.

threat.name: Insider misuse of API access privileges
threat.desc:
General threat description: Insider threats involve malicious activities conducted by individuals within the organization who have authorized access to the ELB API. Insiders can misuse their access privileges to steal data, disrupt operations, or sabotage systems.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include disgruntled employees, contractors, or business partners who have legitimate access to the system.

Impacts: Insider threats can result in data breaches, financial losses, damage to reputation, and legal consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An employee with access to sensitive data copies and sells the information to a competitor.
  • A contractor deliberately plants malware on the system, causing disruptions to services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized API access
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized API access occurs when an attacker gains access to the ELB API without proper authentication. This can lead to unauthorized actions such as modifying load balancer configurations, adding or removing instances, and disrupting application availability.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include malicious actors who use stolen API keys, credentials, or exploit vulnerabilities in the authentication mechanism.

Impacts: Unauthorized access can result in service disruptions, data breaches, financial loss, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses stolen API keys to access and reconfigure the load balancer, redirecting traffic to malicious servers.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the API authentication mechanism to gain unauthorized access and disrupt services.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized ELB configuration changes
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized configuration changes involve an attacker modifying the ELB settings without proper authorization. This can disrupt traffic distribution, degrade performance, or expose sensitive data.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include malicious actors exploiting stolen credentials, API keys, or security vulnerabilities to alter configuration settings.

Impacts: Unauthorized changes can lead to application downtime, data breaches, and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses stolen API keys to change the ELB configuration, redirecting traffic to malicious servers.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the ELB API to alter settings and disrupt service availability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

weakness.name: CWE-116
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-116: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

weakness.name: CWE-1282
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1282: Assumed-Immutable Data is Stored in Writable Memory Immutable data, such as a first-stage bootloader, device identifiers, and "write-once" configuration settings are stored in writable memory that can be re-programmed or updated in the field.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-267
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-267: Privilege Defined With Unsafe Actions A particular privilege, role, capability, or right can be used to perform unsafe actions that were not intended, even when it is assigned to the correct entity.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-707
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-707: Improper Neutralization The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Apply guardrails and prompt validation for LLM interactions
countermeasure.desc:
1. Understand Constrained Prompt Templates:

    Meet with your development team to ensure they fully understand the concept of constrained prompt templates. These templates are specifically formulated inputs for the Language Model (LLM) that prevent it from generating inappropriate or risky responses. The prompts should be designed to limit the context and content scope strictly.

  2. Design and Implement Prompt Templates:

    Develop prompt templates that restrict the LLM's behavior to desired boundaries. For instance, if the LLM interacts with sensitive systems, ensure the prompts do not encourage actions outside the approved commands. Test these templates extensively to verify they accurately constrain the model's responses.

  3. Create Tool Invocation Policies:

    Establish clear policies regarding how and when tools and scripts can be invoked by the LLM. Define acceptable actions and create documented rules that the system should enforce automatically. This might involve setting up role-based access controls or context-aware access policies to ensure that only authorized actions can be performed.

  4. Implement Monitoring Mechanisms:

    Deploy a robust monitoring system that logs all LLM interactions and outputs. Technologies such as SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) can be employed to analyze the logs for anomalies or unauthorized actions. Invest in tools that offer real-time monitoring and alerting capabilities.

  5. Validate Output Commands:

    Before executing any command generated by the LLM, ensure that a validation mechanism is in place. Implement a manual or automated review process to inspect these commands. Automated processes might use predefined rules to check the command syntax and utility against expected behaviors.

  6. Continuous Testing and Updates:

    Regularly test the entire security setup and update the prompt templates and tool invocation policies as the threat landscape evolves. Consider breach and attack simulation exercises to identify any potential weaknesses in the system.

  7. Training and Awareness:

    Conduct workshops and training sessions for all stakeholders involved with the MCP Client, ensuring they understand the security measures and their roles in following these practices consistently. This will increase adherence to policies and help in recognizing and reporting suspicious activity promptly.

References

  • Security Framework Implementation Guide

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1040 - Behavior Prevention on Endpoint

countermeasure.name: Authenticate and authorize all client requests
countermeasure.desc:
1. Implement Token-Based Authentication:
    • Choose a token-based authentication mechanism such as OAuth 2.0 or JSON Web Tokens (JWT).
    • For OAuth 2.0, configure an authorization server within your infrastructure, or use a trusted third-party service, to issue access tokens.
    • Ensure that tokens are short-lived and follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the necessary permissions.
    • Incorporate token refresh mechanisms to minimize the risk of token theft, allowing clients to refresh their tokens after expiry without re-authentication.
  2. Implement Certificate-Based Authentication:
    • Set up a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to manage and issue digital certificates for client authentication.
    • Enroll clients to obtain valid certificates by providing a secure registration process, possibly involving manual verification steps.
    • On each client-server interaction, validate the client's certificate against a Certificate Authority (CA) chain of trust.
    • Adopt revocation lists or Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) to promptly revoke compromised or expired certificates.
  3. Include Origin Verification:
    • Check the Origin or Referer header in HTTP requests to verify that requests are coming from legitimate domains.
    • Implement CORS policies on the server to only allow requests from trusted client origins.
    • Log and monitor all requests, paying particular attention to any unexpected Origin headers or anomalies.
  4. Implement Per-Client API Keys:
    • Generate unique API keys for each client that needs to access the MCP service.
    • Store the generated API keys securely using hashing algorithms, never storing raw keys in your databases.
    • Associate API keys with each client's profile, enabling key-based request validation and rate limiting per client.
    • Establish a secure process for clients to regenerate keys in case of compromise or loss.

References

  • Awesome MCP Security - Identity & Authentication

countermeasure.name: Encrypt communication channels with TLS
countermeasure.desc:
1. Upgrade to TLS 1.3 or Newer:

    • Identify all communication channels between the MCP Client, other tools, and servers that currently use older versions of TLS or no encryption.
    • Update the software dependencies and libraries in use to versions that support TLS 1.3 or newer. Many modern programming languages and frameworks have built-in support for TLS 1.3, including OpenSSL 1.1.1 or later, which should be utilized.
    • Work with your network team to ensure that any intermediary network devices such as proxies, load balancers, or firewalls are also updated to support TLS 1.3.
    • Test the updated connection mechanisms in a development environment to verify that they are properly encrypting all data as expected.

  2. Disable Plaintext Fallback:

    • Configure both the client-side and server-side systems to prohibit downgrades to plain HTTP or any protocol that doesnt utilize encryption. This usually involves setting strict rules within the application configuration files.
    • Employ HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security) policies which can help browsers ensure that connections to the server are always made over HTTPS.
    • Test the connection from different clients to ensure that attempts to downgrade encryption are blocked and logged for auditing purposes.

  3. Enforce Certificate Validation:

    • Ensure that the MCP Client is configured to validate the SSL/TLS certificates during the handshake process. This should include verifying that the certificate is signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA), and that the certificate is not expired or revoked.
    • Implement a mechanism to use Certificate Pinning where feasible, which associates a host with their valid public key, thus reducing the risk of man-in-the-middle attacks.
    • Regularly update the client-side trusted CA store to include only those CAs you trust, removing any that are no longer considered secure.
    • Validate that any exceptions to certificate validation (such as self-signed certificates) are carefully controlled and documented in compliance with best practices.

  4. Regular Reviews and Updates:

    • Set up a schedule for regularly reviewing the TLS configurations and certificates used across your MCP Client's communication architecture.
    • Maintain documentation for all changes made to the communication security settings, capturing any risk assessments conducted as part of these updates.

References

  • awesome-mcp-security#tls-and-encryption

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict schema validation and version negotiation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP Client, it is crucial to validate request and response schemas on both client and server sides. This process ensures that data exchanged between the client and the server adheres to defined standards, reducing vulnerabilities and miscommunication risks.

  1. Schema Definition: Define a formal schema for requests and responses using a schema definition language like JSON Schema or XML Schema. This schema will act as a contract between client and server.
    • Identify all possible request and response structures used by the MCP Client.
    • Create a JSON/XML schema for each identified structure, outlining expected fields, data types, and constraints.
  2. Schema Validation Implementation: Use a schema validation library appropriate for the programming language of the MCP Client and server.
    • Incorporate the chosen validation library into the client and server codebases.
    • Implement logic to trigger schema validation before processing requests and constructing responses.
    • Log validation errors and handle them gracefully, refusing to process invalid data.
  3. Version Tags and Backward Compatibility: Use version tags within your schema to manage changes over time and maintain compatibility.
    • Include a version attribute in your schema to label different iterations (e.g., v1, v2).
    • On the server-side, implement checks to determine if incoming requests are compatible with supported versions.
    • Design the system to handle deprecated fields and provide default values when possible to maintain backward compatibility.
  4. Testing and Monitoring: Regularly test schema validation and version handling to ensure robustness and effectiveness.
    • Create a suite of test cases covering valid and invalid request/response scenarios.
    • Automate testing with continuous integration pipelines to quickly identify issues.
    • Monitor logs for schema validation errors and resolve discrepancies to improve schema accuracy.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

countermeasure.name: Implement timeouts for tool calls
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the MCP Client from potential abuse or inadvertent hangs, it is essential to implement strict per-call timeouts and maximum execution windows for backend tools. These measures ensure that individual requests do not consume excessive resources or lead to prolonged execution that could affect system performance or availability. Here's a detailed guide to implementing these security countermeasures:

  1. Identify Critical API Calls:
    • Begin by mapping out all backend API calls made by the MCP Client.
    • Prioritize API calls that have historically experienced long execution times or are crucial to system operations.
  2. Set Per-Call Timeout Values:
    • For each API call, define a maximum timeout duration that reflects a balance between performance needs and security considerations.
    • Consider historical data and current system performance metrics to establish these timeout values.
    • Implement these timeout values in the code where API calls are executed, ensuring that any excess time results in a controlled termination of the process.
  3. Define Maximum Execution Windows:
    • Determine acceptable execution windows, taking into account business hours and periods of expected high usage.
    • Restrict operation times for maintenance or auxiliary tasks that do not need to run during peak hours.
    • Use scheduling tools to enforce these execution windows, ensuring processes automatically cease operation outside allowed times.
  4. Implement Monitoring and Alerts:
    • Deploy monitoring tools to oversee execution durations and timeout occurrences.
    • Set up alerts to notify administrators when timeouts are frequently triggered, indicating potential abuse or misconfiguration.
  5. Regularly Review and Adjust Policies:
    • Conduct periodic reviews of timeout settings and execution windows to ensure they still meet operational and security requirements.
    • Stay informed of any changes in usage patterns or system upgrades that may affect current settings.

By following these steps, you can effectively apply timeouts and execution windows to enhance the security and reliability of MCP Client operations.

References

  • Model Context Protocol (MCP): Landscape, Security Threats, and Future Research Directions

countermeasure.name: Log tool usage for audit purposes
countermeasure.desc:
• Begin by integrating a logging mechanism into the MCP Client application. This mechanism should capture and record every invocation of tools within the application environment. The log entries must include a timestamp, the exact input used during the invocation, and the identity of the user who initiated the action.
  • Ensure that the logging system is performant and operates efficiently to prevent any bottlenecks or performance degradation in the MCP Client application. Consider using a logging library or framework that supports high-throughput environments and is compatible with the application's technology stack.
  • Implement authentication and authorization controls to verify user identity before any tool invocation is allowed. This process should align with the organization's existing identity and access management policies. Use technologies such as OAuth, OpenID Connect, or similar for consistent and reliable user identity verification.
  • Configure the logging mechanism to output logs in a structured format such as JSON or XML. This facilitates easy parsing and analysis by downstream systems and maintains consistency across all logs.
  • Set up a dedicated secure log storage system, such as a central logging server or a specialized log management solution. Ensure that this system has access controls in place to protect against unauthorized access to logs. Tools like ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) or Splunk can be employed for secure log storage and management.
  • Incorporate cryptographic measures to provide integrity guarantees for stored logs. Techniques such as log signing or hashing can be implemented to detect any unauthorized modifications to log entries. Consider using algorithms like SHA-256 in combination with digital signatures.
  • Regularly audit the integrity of stored logs. Develop automated scripts or use tools that verify the integrity of logs by comparing current hashes to previous records.
  • Establish data retention policies in compliance with organizational standards and legal requirements. Securely archive or delete logs that exceed the retention period to maintain operational efficiency and compliance.
  • Periodically review the entire logging, storage, and integrity verification process. Update and refine practices as necessary to adapt to new threats or technological changes while ensuring adherence to regulatory requirements.

References

  • arXiv: Logging and Monitoring in Secure Systems

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Prompt for user confirmation on sensitive operations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security management in the MCP Client, implementing a confirmation prompt before executing privileged actions is critical. This process ensures that every action requiring elevated privileges is adequately verified, protecting against unauthorized or accidental execution of potentially harmful operations. Below is a step-by-step guide to implementing this countermeasure:

  1. Identify Privileged Actions:
    • Review the MCP Client functionalities to determine all actions considered privileged.
    • Document these actions for reference and future audit purposes.
  2. Develop User Interface for Confirmation:
    • Design a user-friendly confirmation dialog that clearly describes the action being requested.
    • Ensure the prompt includes actionable buttons such as "Confirm" and "Cancel" to allow users to approve or deny the action.
    • Implement accessibility features in the confirmation dialog, adhering to accessibility standards.
  3. Integrate Confirmation Prompt in the Client Workflow:
    • Embed the confirmation prompt trigger in the workflow just before the execution of each identified privileged action.
    • Ensure the action is only executed after receiving explicit confirmation from the user.
  4. Audit Logging:
    • Implement logging for each confirmation prompt interaction to record timestamps, user responses, and actions requested.
    • Regularly audit these logs to identify and investigate any unauthorized or suspicious activity.
  5. User Training and Awareness:
    • Conduct training sessions for users on the importance of the confirmation prompts and how to interact with them safely.
    • Provide documentation and support channels for any inquiries or issues faced by users concerning the confirmation process.

This approach not only adds a layer of verification but also empowers users to make informed decisions, significantly reducing the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches.

References

  • Implementation of Security Considerations in Software Systems

countermeasure.name: Refactor the MCP client to dynamically fetch endpoints from a secure configuration service
countermeasure.desc:
Hardcoding the IP addresses or hostnames of your backend model servers in the gateway's configuration makes your system fragile, difficult to scale, and insecure. You must refactor your gateway to use a dynamic service discovery pattern. This allows the gateway to automatically learn about new backend instances as they are added, and to stop sending traffic to instances that have failed, dramatically improving the security and resilience of your inference service.

A DevOps engineer or cloud architect should implement this by establishing the following architecture:

  1. Deploy a Central Service Registry
    • You must have a central, highly available service registry that acts as the source of truth for the network locations of all your backend services.
    • In a Kubernetes environment, this is provided natively by the Kubernetes API server and the cluster's internal DNS service.
  2. Implement Automated Service Registration
    • Your backend model inference services must be configured to automatically register themselves with the service registry upon startup and to be automatically de-registered when they are terminated or fail their health checks.
    • In Kubernetes, this is handled automatically when a Pod is added to or removed from a Service object.
  3. Refactor the Gateway for Dynamic Discovery
    • The Inference Gateway must be configured to query the service registry to find its backends.
    • Instead of a static IP, the gateway should be configured with a stable, internal DNS name for the backend service (e.g., fraud-model.production.svc.cluster.local). The service registry is responsible for resolving this name to the list of current, healthy backend IP addresses.
    • The gateway must be designed to honor the Time-to-Live (TTL) of the DNS records and periodically refresh its list of backend endpoints.
  4. Secure the Service Discovery Mechanism
    • The service discovery mechanism itself must be secured. In Kubernetes, this is achieved by using network policies to control which applications are allowed to resolve which internal services, and by using mutual TLS (mTLS) from a service mesh to authenticate communication.

References:

  • Cloud Design Patterns: Service Discovery pattern
  • Kubernetes Documentation: Service

countermeasure.name: Sanitize inputs before execution
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP Client by implementing input whitelisting and sensitive data redaction mechanisms, follow the step-by-step guidance outlined below:

  1. Identify Input Sources:
    • Examine all areas where user input is collected, such as forms, API endpoints, and file uploads.
    • Ensure each input point is clearly documented, specifying the expected data type and format.
  2. Define Input Whitelisting Rules:
    • Create a whitelist for each input field in your application. This should include valid characters, data types, and lengths.
    • For example, when expecting an email address, whitelist entries should allow alphanumeric characters, periods, and the "@" symbol only.
    • Document these rules for consistency and future reference.
  3. Implement Input Validation:
    • Apply the whitelisting rules at the entry point of the application. Use server-side validation to enforce these rules.
    • Consider using third-party libraries or frameworks with built-in validation functionalities to minimize the chances of errors and enhance efficiency.
    • Test your input filters against common injection attacks to ensure robustness.
  4. Network and Application Logging:
    • Implement logging at input validation points to capture details about invalid or malicious input attempts.
    • Utilize these logs to analyze and refine whitelisting rules as new patterns emerge.
  5. Develop Sensitive Data Redaction Mechanism:
    • Identify data classifications considered sensitive, such as personal identification numbers, credit card information, and addresses.
    • Implement data masking or redaction techniques to either remove sensitive data elements or replace them with placeholder values upon initial intake.
    • Ensure that redaction mechanisms are part of your data processing pipeline, particularly before data storage or transmission over networks.
  6. Regular Auditing and Updates:
    • Schedule regular audits to review and update the whitelisting rules and redaction processes, adapting to new security threats or business needs.
    • Stay informed about security advisories related to the technologies and frameworks you employ to respond promptly to known vulnerabilities.

Implementing these strategies will significantly mitigate risks associated with arbitrary data submissions and ensure sensitive information is appropriately managed within the MCP Client.

References

  • Awesome MCP Security - Input Sanitization

countermeasure.name: Show tool inputs to the user before calling the server
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP Client, it is essential to implement a mechanism that allows users to review and approve all arguments and content before they are transmitted to backend tools. This procedure ensures transparency and user control over data being processed and transmitted, thus mitigating potential security risks such as unintended data disclosure or execution of unauthorized commands.

  1. Integrate a Display Interface:
    • Develop a user interface element within the MCP Client that presents a detailed view of all arguments and content that will be sent to backend tools.
    • Ensure the interface is easily accessible and clear, avoiding technical jargon where possible to accommodate users of varying technical expertise.
  2. Prompt User Inspection:
    • Before any data is transmitted, trigger a modal or dialog that interrupts the transaction, displaying all pertinent information to the user.
    • Information should be structured in a way that highlights key data points and any potentially sensitive data.
  3. Implement User Approval Mechanism:
    • Include a clear approval step, such as a checkbox or confirmation button, that users must actively engage with to proceed with the transmission.
    • Ensure this step is mandatory and that the user must consciously approve the data being sent. Automate reminders or warnings if the user tries to bypass this step.
  4. Log User Actions for Auditing:
    • Implement logging mechanisms to record user actions related to data inspection and approval. Logs should detail when and what data was approved.
    • Secure the logs against unauthorized access and ensure they are periodically reviewed for discrepancies or unusual activity.
  5. Regularly Update and Review the Data Display Logic:
    • Continually assess which arguments and data should be displayed based on the evolving backend tools and processes.
    • Conduct regular updates and user feedback sessions to improve the inspection interface and ensure it meets user needs effectively.

By incorporating these steps into the MCP Client, users are empowered to make informed decisions about the data being shared with backend tools, thus greatly enhancing the overall security posture of the system.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

countermeasure.name: Validate tool results before passing to LLM
countermeasure.desc:
1. Integrate Data Integrity Checks:
    • Implement cryptographic hashing functions on data transmitted from backend tools to ensure that the data has not been altered in transit. Use algorithms like SHA-256 or SHA-512 for robust hash generation.
    • Establish a protocol where backend data sends its hash along with the data, and the MCP Client recalculates the hash upon receipt to verify integrity.
  2. Preprocess Backend Responses:
    • Implement a middleware application that intercepts all backend tool responses before they reach the LLM inference system.
    • This middleware should be capable of executing the following filtering operations:
      • Remove or sanitize any unauthorized or unexpected HTML tags, scripts, or commands that could be potentially harmful.
      • Apply whitelisting strategies to only allow known safe data and block everything else.
  3. Apply Schema Validation:
    • Define a robust data schema that delineates the expected structure and format of the data coming from backend tools.
    • Utilize JSON Schema or XML Schema validation libraries to programmatically enforce these rules, ensuring any deviation or unexpected data format is flagged and handled appropriately.
  4. Detect Anomalies or Malicious Formatting:
    • Implement anomaly detection algorithms using statistical methods and machine learning to spot deviations from typical data patterns that signify a security threat.
    • Customize the algorithm to be sensitive enough to detect malicious data patterns or formatting that could attempt to exploit the LLM inference system.
    • Regularly update the anomaly patterns and retrain models with the latest threat data to stay resilient against evolving tactics.
  5. Continual Monitoring and Logging:
    • Set up comprehensive logging for all data interactions related to the MCP Client interface.
    • Monitor logs for signs of tampering, unusual data formats, or unauthorized access. Use SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) tools for real-time alerting and analysis.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of service via uncontrolled tool invocation
threat.desc:
General threat description
The system may become unresponsive or slow due to repeated or long-running tool calls, which can exhaust system resources or interfere with the normal operation of the LLM interaction loop. This can significantly degrade the user experience.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unoptimized system processes or malicious actors running scripts or applications that continuously call tools without limits or breaks.
Impacts
Degradation of system performance, poor user experience, potential system crashes, and denial of service to legitimate users.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker deliberately writes a script that continuously sends requests to exhaust resources. 2. A poorly-designed application or system feature erroneously triggers repeated calls, saturating available resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service||ATLAS - AML.T0016 - Obtain Capabilities||ATLAS - AML.T0016.001 - Software Tools

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unpredictable behavior from LLM outputs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unexpected behavior from tool chaining or unstable prompts might result in the MCP client executing commands that are disruptive, unsafe, or not intended by the user.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attack vectors can include malicious scripts or manipulative prompts designed to exploit vulnerabilities in the tool chaining process, potentially triggered by unauthorized users or external malicious actors.
Impacts
The impacts of these executions can include system instability, data corruption, unauthorized access or loss of sensitive information, and potential disruptions to business operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example attack scenario might involve a compromised MCP client where unexpected tool chaining causes it to execute harmful scripts, leading to data loss or system compromise. Another scenario could involve a tampered prompt initiating unintended processes that disrupt normal operations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1202 - Indirect Command Execution||ATLAS - AML.T0054 - LLM Jailbreak

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of critical endpoints in client-side source code
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The source code of the MCP client, which is publicly accessible, contains hardcoded URLs to sensitive internal or administrative API endpoints. This allows an attacker to discover and directly target undocumented and potentially unsecured functionalities of the backend infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious users, security researchers, automated vulnerability scanners.
  • Vectors: Inspecting JavaScript files in browser developer tools, decompiling client-side applications, or running string searches on the client's source code for URL patterns and keywords like "admin" or "debug."

Impacts

  • Security Control Bypass: Attackers can directly interact with internal services, potentially bypassing critical security layers like the main API gateway, authentication checks, or rate limiting.
  • Increased Attack Surface: The exposed endpoints provide attackers with a map of the internal infrastructure and reveal hidden features that can be probed for other vulnerabilities.
  • Unauthorized Administrative Actions: If an exposed endpoint controls a sensitive function (e.g., deleting models, reconfiguring a service) and is improperly secured, an attacker could cause significant damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker inspects the minified JavaScript of the web client and finds a commented-out endpoint URL for /api/v2/admin/force_resync_all_models, which they successfully call.
  • A security researcher analyzes the source code of the open-source client library and discovers an endpoint for a debugging service that, when accessed, reveals live operational metrics and environment variables.
  • A malicious user decompiles the client executable and finds a hardcoded URL to a legacy, unauthenticated endpoint that allows for stopping and starting training jobs outside the normal control plane.

threat.name: Unintentional data exfiltration via LLM input
threat.desc:
General threat description
Automatic tool chaining can result in the MCP client inadvertently sharing sensitive data without the user's awareness or approval, posing a risk of unintended data exposure.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors could exploit automatic processes within the MCP client to intercept or redirect sensitive data during communication, leveraging automated toolchains without requiring direct user interaction or detection.
Impacts
The unauthorized sharing of sensitive data can lead to data breaches, loss of confidentiality, reputational damage, regulatory penalties, and potential financial losses for the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker manipulates process automation scripts to reroute sensitive information from the MCP client to their own servers, bypassing security controls. 2. Automated integration with third-party services leads to transmission of confidential data without explicit user consent, potentially exposing the information to external parties. 3. Malicious exploitation of a misconfigured automation tool to extract and publicly expose sensitive user details through the MCP client.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1005 - Data from Local System||ATLAS - AML.T0010.002 - Data||ATLAS - AML.T0057 - LLM Data Leakage

threat.name: Insecure communication with backend tools
threat.desc:
General threat description
The MCP client may communicate with tools over unencrypted channels, which poses a risk of interception, tampering, or replay of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit unencrypted communication channels between the MCP client and tools to access or manipulate transmitted data.
Impacts
Sensitive information may be exposed, leading to data breaches or unauthorized access. Additionally, data integrity may be compromised if information is altered during transmission.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts unencrypted data being transmitted between the MCP client and a connected tool, obtaining sensitive information such as credentials or confidential business data. In another scenario, an attacker conducts a replay attack by capturing the data and resending it to perform unauthorized actions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1557 - Adversary-in-the-Middle||ATLAS - AML.T0016 - Obtain Capabilities||ATLAS - AML.T0016.001 - Software Tools

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of non-repudiation for tool usage
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of persistent logging within the MCP Client allows operations to be executed by users or attackers without any accountability or traceability, making it difficult to maintain audit trails.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Potential threat agents include unauthorized users or insiders who exploit the absence of logging to perform untraceable actions. Attack vectors may involve executing critical operations bypassing traditional monitoring systems.
Impacts
The primary impact is the inability to reconstruct or understand user actions, leading to challenges in forensic investigations, compliance violations, and increased potential for undetected malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An unauthorized individual gains access to the MCP Client and makes changes to critical system configurations. Due to the lack of logs, security teams are unable to determine the source or nature of the changes made.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1054 - Indicator Blocking||ATLAS - AML.T0016.001 - Software Tools

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Impersonation of the MCP client
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could spoof or mimic a legitimate MCP client to submit unauthorized tool usage requests, leading to potential data leaks or misuse of resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or malicious insiders who can impersonate an MCP client through system vulnerabilities or insufficient client authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, misuse of enterprise tools and resources, potential data leaks, and compromised system integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts network traffic to capture legitimate MCP client credentials and then uses those credentials to gain access to restricted tools, leading to extraction of confidential information or unauthorized execution of commands. Alternatively, an insider with enough knowledge of the system mimics an MCP client to access resources they are ordinarily not authorized to use, resulting in data leakage or operational disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1656 - Impersonation||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Operational errors due to schema inconsistencies
threat.desc:
General threat description
If the client and backend tools do not adhere to compatible schemas, errors or misinterpretations could lead to incorrect behavior or data corruption.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Developers failing to coordinate schema updates between the client-side application and backend services, or neglecting to implement validation checks.
Impacts
Possible data inconsistency, integrity issues, and potentially significant errors in application logic that can result in flawed decision-making or system failures.
Example Attack Scenarios
A client application is updated with a new data format, but the backend remains on the old version, leading to failed data transactions and corrupted database entries. Another scenario is where a backend update changes a field type, rendering the client's data unreadable or unprocessable.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

weakness.name: CWE-116
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-116: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-288
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-288: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel A product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-345
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: CWE-706
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-706: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt stored tokens and implement token rotation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of OAuth tokens on the MCP Server, it is essential to protect them with encryption when stored and ensure their limited lifespan by periodically rotating them. The following steps outline the process required to implement these measures:

  1. Choose a Strong Encryption Algorithm: Adopt Advanced Encryption Standard with a 256-bit key (AES-256) for encrypting OAuth tokens at rest. This algorithm is widely regarded for its robustness and efficiency, providing a high level of security.

  2. Implement Token Encryption: Utilize a cryptographic library compatible with AES-256 to encrypt the tokens before storage.

    • Ensure that the encryption process is performed whenever a token is created or updated.
    • Store the encrypted token securely in the database while keeping the encryption keys protected using a key management service or hardware security module.

  3. Set Short-lived Token Expiry: Configure the OAuth tokens to have a short lifespan (e.g., minutes or hours), depending on the application's specific requirements.

    • Implement mechanisms that automatically revoke or refresh the tokens when their expiry is reached, warning both the server and client beforehand.

  4. Enable Token Rotation: Regularly rotate tokens to limit the impact of any potential token theft. Implement a scheduled process that generates new tokens at predefined intervals (e.g., periodically or upon every access).

    • Ensure that the rotation process maintains session integrity by validating the presence of updated tokens before invalidating the existing ones.
    • Communicate the new tokens securely to the client applications while invalidating the old ones to prevent misuse.

  5. Audit and Monitor: Set up logging mechanisms to monitor token usage, detect anomalies, and track misuse patterns.

    • Use this data to trigger alerts and establish security incident response plans to act promptly on potential threats.

References

  • Model Context Protocol (MCP) vs Security

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce end-to-end encryption and integrity verification
countermeasure.desc:
To secure the MCP Server by requiring TLS 1.3 with strong cipher suites and using digital signatures for ensuring data integrity, follow these detailed steps:

Step 1: Enabling and Configuring TLS 1.3

  1. Update Server Software: Ensure that your server software or application environment (e.g., Apache, Nginx) is updated to the latest version that supports TLS 1.3. Older versions may only support TLS 1.2 or earlier, which have known vulnerabilities.
  2. Configure TLS 1.3: Modify the servers configuration file to specifically enable TLS 1.3. For an Nginx server, this might involve editing the nginx.conf file: 
    ssl_protocols TLSv1.3;
  3. Select Strong Cipher Suites: Configure your server to use strong, recommended cipher suites. For TLS 1.3, the cipher suite selection is simplified. Ensure that you have removed weaker cipher suites from your TLS 1.2 configuration if used concurrently.

Step 2: Implementing Digital Signatures

  1. Establish Digital Signature Strategy: Determine which digital signature methods (e.g., HMAC, ECDSA) suit your needs based on the environment's computing resources and desired level of security. ECDSA typically offers efficient and robust security.
  2. Enable and Configure HMAC: If opting to use HMAC, ensure that your application supports enabling HMAC with an adequate hash function (such as SHA-256 or SHA-384). For instance, in a codebase configuration, include: 
    HMAC_SHA256(key, data);
  3. Implement ECDSA: If selecting ECDSA, ensure that your cryptographic library is current and supports ECDSA. Registration and management of key pairs are critical:
    • Generate an ECDSA key pair (private/public) using tools like OpenSSL.
    • Implement routines to sign data and verify signatures:
      • ECDSA_sign, ECDSA_verify;
  4. Integrate Signature Verification: Incorporate signature verification at the receiving server-side to validate data integrity. This involves adding appropriate code logic to ensure that payloads are verified upon receipt.

Step 3: Testing and Validation

  1. Test the Configuration: Utilize tools like SSL Labs to test and verify the server's TLS configuration. Metrics such as protocol invocation and cipher suite preference should be thoroughly validated to meet the desired security level.
  2. Validate Digital Signatures: Conduct extensive testing of the digital signature process to ensure no data integrity issues during data transmission. Automated tests can affirm the correctness and robustness of signature operations.

Step 4: Maintenance and Monitoring

  1. Regularly Update Software: Keep abreast of security advisories related to TLS and cryptographic libraries to maintain resilience against newly discovered vulnerabilities.
  2. Monitor Logs: Implement logging mechanisms that alert administrators to any failed TLS negotiations or signature verifications, to address potential threats swiftly.

References

  • Model Context Protocol Security Considerations

countermeasure.name: Harden server security and apply token vaulting
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of MCP servers, start by deploying a hardened operating system. A hardened OS is customized to reduce its vulnerability to attacks by minimizing unnecessary services, ports, and potentially exploitable software. Choose a Linux distribution designed for security, such as Ubuntu Server in its Minimal Installation form, or use security-enhanced versions like SELinux or AppArmor.

  1. Install the OS: During installation, select minimal configurations that exclude non-essential services. Use a package manager to remove any redundant software and dependencies.
  2. Configure File Permissions: Ensure that only necessary processes and users have access to critical system files. Utilize tools like 'chmod' and 'chown' to adjust file permissions and ownership appropriately.
  3. Enable SELinux or AppArmor: Configure SELinux or AppArmor to enforce strict access controls at the kernel level. Set these policies to enforcement mode rather than permissive to ensure maximum security efficacy.

Next, limit network exposure by deploying firewalls around the MCP servers. This involves configuring both software firewalls on the server and hardware firewalls at the network perimeter.

  1. Install and Configure Software Firewall: Utilize iptables or a similar firewall solution to control incoming and outgoing traffic based on predefined security rules. Define specific rules that block all traffic except for those needed by the MCP server operations (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS on specific ports).
  2. Setup Hardware Firewall: Implement network-level firewalls at the perimeter of the enterprise network, ensuring they are configured to inspect and filter traffic to the MCP servers specifically. Use these to prevent unauthorized access and detect potential threats early.

Token storage requires particular attention to ensure that sensitive tokens are isolated and protected against unauthorized access.

  1. Deploy a Token Vault: Set up isolated, hardened vault services such as HashiCorp Vault for token storage. This should be configured to operate on a different server from the MCP server to decrease the attack surface.
  2. Configure Vault Policies: Define strict access policies within the vault to determine who or what can retrieve tokens. Utilize role-based access controls (RBAC) to enforce these restrictions.
  3. Enable Auditing: Configure detailed logging within the vault to capture all access attempts to the stored tokens. Monitor and respond to the audit logs for any suspicious activities.

References

  • Overview of MCP Server Security Measures

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and context validation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP Server against resource exhaustion attacks, follow these implementation steps:

Step-by-Step Guidance

  1. Implement API Gateway Rate Limiting:
    1. Select an appropriate API gateway solution that supports rate limiting. Options include AWS API Gateway, Kong, or NGINX.
    2. Define rate limiting policies based on your application's typical usage patterns. Consider factors such as the maximum number of requests per minute/hour and user roles.
    3. Configure rate limiting rules within the API gateway:
      • Create rules to limit the number of requests per IP address per given time frame.
      • Set different thresholds for different types of users (e.g., authenticated vs. unauthenticated).
    4. Test the rate limiting configuration in a staging environment to ensure that legitimate traffic is not being inadvertently blocked.
  2. Validate Incoming Context Payloads:
    1. Define acceptable payload size limits based on your application's needs and the average size of expected requests.
    2. Implement input validation on incoming requests:
      • Checking the size of incoming payloads to ensure it does not exceed the predefined limit.
      • Verifying the structure of the payload to match expected schemas or formats.
    3. Use libraries or frameworks that support schema validation to simplify this process. Options include JSON Schema for JSON payloads.
    4. Regularly update validation rules to adapt to new threats and ensure comprehensive coverage.
  3. Monitoring and Logging:
    1. Ensure that the API gateway logs rate limiting events for analysis and tuning of thresholds.
    2. Set up alerts to notify administrators of any unusual or excessive request patterns.
    3. Analyze logs regularly to refine rate limits and validation rules.
  4. Documentation and Training:
    1. Document the implemented rate limiting and validation strategies.
    2. Conduct training sessions for developers and system administrators on the importance and practices of API security.

References

  • The Security Risks of Model Context Protocol (MCP)

countermeasure.name: Implement role-based access control with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the MCP server by configuring strict Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), follow these steps:

  1. Review Existing Roles and Permissions:
    • Access the MCP server's current configuration of roles and permissions.
    • Document all existing roles, ensuring clarity on what each role is intended to perform.
    • Identify permissions granted to each role and cross-reference with their necessity for performing assigned tasks.
  2. Define and Assign Minimal Roles:
    • Create a comprehensive list of tasks that need to be performed by users and services interacting with the MCP server.
    • Design roles around these tasks, ensuring minimal overlap and role-specific permissions.
    • Assign these newly defined roles to users and services according to their functional requirements.
  3. Implement Principle of Least Privilege:
    • Ensure each role has only the permissions necessary to perform their associated tasks.
    • Remove any superfluous permissions or conglomerated roles not aligned with the Principle of Least Privilege (PoLP).
  4. Configure and Test RBAC Policies:
    • Access the configuration settings for the MCP server and apply the newly defined roles and permissions.
    • Conduct thorough testing to verify that each role can perform necessary functions without bypassing security restrictions.
    • Engage in penetration testing or simulation of attacks to ensure that no unauthorized access is possible under the new configuration.
  5. Audit and Monitor Roles and Access:
    • Set up logging to monitor role assignments and access patterns continuously.
    • Perform regular audits to ensure that the roles and permissions align with organizational needs and adjust them as necessary.
  6. Educate and Train Users:
    • Conduct training for users and administrators to help them understand the importance of RBAC and their responsibilities.
    • Provide documentation and resources that detail how to work within the RBAC policies as defined.
  7. Maintain and Update RBAC Configuration:
    • Regularly review and update RBAC settings as new services are added or removed, or as organizational requirements evolve.
    • Respond promptly to any breaches or instances where access control polices fail by refining policies to cover any identified gaps.

Implementing these strategies ensures robust security by deploying a well-structured RBAC configuration that limits access strictly based on necessity.

References

  • MCP Server Development Guide

countermeasure.name: Implement strong client authentication
countermeasure.desc:
1. Install and Configure the Required Software:
    • Ensure that your MCP server and client systems have a compatible version of OpenSSL or a similar library that supports mutual TLS (mTLS).
    • Ensure that your server software (such as Apache, Nginx, or any MCP-specific server) supports mTLS. You may need to install or enable additional modules for your server.
  2. Generate Server and Client Certificates:
    • Create a Certificate Authority (CA) if you don't already have one. This CA will be used to sign the server and client certificates.
    • Generate a private key and a certificate signing request (CSR) for the server. Submit the CSR to your CA to obtain the server certificate.
    • Repeat the above step for each client that needs to connect to the MCP server, ensuring that each client has a unique certificate signed by your CA.
  3. Configure the MCP Server for mTLS:
    • Edit the server configuration file to enable TLS. This typically involves specifying the path to the server's private key and certificate, and the CA's certificate that can validate client certificates.
    • Enable client certificate verification. In Apache, for example, this can be done by setting SSLVerifyClient require and specifying the verification depth.
    • Configure the list of trusted CAs that the server should use to verify client certificates. It should include the CA that signed your client certificates.
  4. Client Configuration:
    • Ensure each client is configured to use its own private key and certificate when connecting to the MCP server. The client must also trust the server's certificate, typically by including the server's CA certificate.
    • Update your client software's configuration files to enable mTLS during connections. This often involves specifying the path to the client's certificate and private key.
  5. Testing and Validation:
    • Test the connection between your clients and the MCP server to ensure that mTLS is functioning correctly. The server should reject any client connections that do not present a valid certificate.
    • Review server logs to verify successful and failed authentication attempts. Logs can help diagnose issues related to certificate validation.
  6. Ongoing Management:
    • Regularly audit and rotate client certificates to reduce the risk of credential compromise.
    • Monitor for any unsupported or deprecated TLS versions and ciphers in your server configuration to maintain strong encryption standards.

References

  • Model Context Protocol Security Considerations

countermeasure.name: Output filtering and LLM containment
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that any output generated by the LLM in response to tool schemas, context inputs, or user queries is thoroughly inspected before it is returned to the calling system or user. This countermeasure protects against information disclosure, prompt injection amplification, data leakage, and the unintended execution of harmful content by downstream systems.

1. Enforce output sanitization and redaction policies

  • Implement a post-generation policy engine that inspects every LLM response.
    • Sanitize outputs by escaping or removing risky content (e.g., embedded shell commands, secrets, tokens).
    • Redact matches against known sensitive patterns (e.g., private key headers, AWS keys, email addresses).
    • Normalize outputs to remove encoding tricks (e.g., base64 in HTML, Unicode obfuscation).

2. Apply token-level scanning and pattern matching

  • Use regular expressions or token classifiers to detect:
    • Sensitive identifiers (e.g., PRIVATE KEY, Authorization: Bearer, token=...)
    • Dangerous language (e.g., rm -rf, wget http://, exec()
    • Leakage of system metadata (e.g., file paths, usernames, .env variables)
  • Consider implementing allowlists and blocklists based on project-specific sensitivity thresholds.

3. Define and enforce output boundaries

  • Set character count or token limits on outputs.
  • Truncate overly long completions or responses that exceed expected formats.
  • Disallow or flag unexpected structures (e.g., full file dumps, multiline code blocks) where inappropriate.

4. Implement configurable LLM containment modes

  • Provide configurable response enforcement levels:
    • Passive: Log violations but allow the response.
    • Active: Redact or replace matched content.
    • Strict: Reject and regenerate the response or return an error.
  • Tie enforcement level to the trust level of the request context (e.g., tool source, LLM prompt origin, or user session).

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1054 - Software Configuration||ATLAS - AML.M0002 - Passive AI Output Obfuscation

countermeasure.name: Request minimal permission scopes and monitor token usage
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively implement a least privilege model when dealing with OAuth scopes on the MCP Server, adhere to the following guidelines:

  1. Inventory OAuth Scopes:

    Start by listing all the OAuth scopes currently used by the MCP Server. Categorize these based on the services they access and evaluate their necessity. This provides a foundational understanding necessary before implementing a least privilege model.

  2. Determine Scope Requirements:

    For each application or service consuming your API, determine the minimal set of OAuth scopes required to function correctly. Avoid configuring scopes that provide full service access unless there is a specific justification.

  3. Update OAuth Configurations:

    Modify OAuth configurations to ensure that only essential scopes are requested. This can be done through your identity providers interface by tailoring OAuth client settings to the least privilege required. Validate these settings by performing integration tests to confirm that operations continue successfully with the reduced scopes.

  4. Monitor API Usage:

    Implement a logging mechanism to continuously monitor API requests and their corresponding OAuth scopes usage. Use tools such as API gateways or log aggregators to analyze this data. Monitor for patterns such as unusual access times, frequency of access, or unexpected scope usage, which could indicate potential anomalies.

  5. Review and Adjust Periodically:

    Regularly review the OAuth scope configurations and usage logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege model. Conduct periodic audits to assess whether the current scopes are still relevant and appropriately scoped based on evolving business requirements.

Implementing these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your MCP Server by reducing the attack surface associated with OAuth scopes.

References

  • What is MCP in AI? Everything You Wanted to Ask!

countermeasure.name: Sanitize AI inputs and validate user intent before execution
countermeasure.desc:
1. Analyze and Identify High-Risk Actions: Begin by reviewing all AI-driven requests and their interactions with the MCP server. Identify commands or actions that have significant operational, financial, or security implications. List these high-risk actions to target in the validation and confirmation process.
  2. Implement Strict Input Validation:
    • Use whitelisting techniques to allow only pre-approved inputs and commands. This restricts the input space to safe commands.
    • Set up character restrictions, ensuring that inputs follow expected data types, lengths, and patterns such as using regex for format validation.
    • Employ sanitization routines to remove any malicious scripts or code that might be injected through AI-driven requests. Make sure to escape input to prevent XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) and other injection attacks.
  3. Integrate Confirmation Dialogs:
    • Design dialogs that prompt confirmation for actions deemed high-risk. Ensure these dialogs clearly present the consequence of executing the action and require explicit user acknowledgment before proceeding.
    • For sensitive operations, implement a dual-confirmation mechanism where a secondary validation or authorization is required from a different user or system administrator.
  4. Utilize AI-Based Anomaly Detection:
    • Incorporate AI models to monitor normal behavior patterns and flag unusual or out-of-pattern requests. This proactive monitoring helps detect potential malicious actions sparked by compromised AI interactions.
    • Set thresholds and alerts for detected anomalies that require immediate administrative attention and manual inspection.
  5. Testing and Validation:
    • Conduct thorough testing to ensure that the input validation and confirmation dialogs are functioning correctly. Utilize test scenarios to simulate both regular and malicious AI-driven requests.
    • Validate that legitimate operations are not inadvertently blocked and that all flagged actions receive the necessary confirmation before execution.
  6. Update and Maintain:
    • Regularly update the validation logic to incorporate new threat intelligence and adjust the confirmation processes as needed.
    • Conduct periodic reviews and audits of the MCP server's interaction logs to refine security protocols and ensure ongoing compliance with the latest security practices.

References

  • AI Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Security

countermeasure.name: Trusted schema enforcement
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that the MCP server accepts, stores, and serves only tool schemas that have been thoroughly validated, signed, and protected from unauthorized modification. This involves implementing secure schema ingestion, integrity enforcement, and lifecycle control mechanisms.

1. Comprehensive schema validation (on ingestion)

  • Validate each incoming tool schema against a strict, server-side JSON Schema specification that defines:
    • Allowed fields (e.g., description, parameters, required, default, enum)
    • Data types, formats, min/max constraints, and required fields
    • Rejection of unknown or unsupported fields (e.g., x-malicious)
  • Reject schemas that:
    • Use ambiguous or over-permissive structures (e.g., type: any)
    • Contain embedded code, secrets, or suspicious default values
  • Implement schema validation as a mandatory check before persisting the schema to any backend store.

2. Enforce immutability of trusted schemas

  • Once a schema is accepted and marked as trusted or approved, lock it:
    • Prevent any future overwrites or edits through normal API workflows.
    • Require versioning: modifications must result in a new version (e.g., v2) with a different immutable ID.
  • Log every version and store a hash (e.g., SHA-256) of each version for later integrity checks.

3. Verify digital signatures

  • Require schema submissions to include a detached or embedded digital signature, signed using a known tool provider's private key.
  • Validate the signature using the public key registered for that tool provider:
    • Reject schemas with missing or invalid signatures.
    • Support revocation/rotation of public keys via a key registry or trust store.
  • Protect against replay attacks by associating signed schemas with unique, non-reusable identifiers or timestamps.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program||ATLAS - AML.M0014 - Verify AI Artifacts

countermeasure.name: Unique tool identification and naming validation
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent tool shadowing, typosquatting, and spoofing attacks by ensuring that each tool registered on the MCP server has a verifiable, globally unique identity, and that naming conventions are enforced consistently to block lookalike or ambiguous identifiers.

1. Enforce globally unique tool identifiers

  • Assign or require submission of a globally unique identifier (GUID or UUID) for every tool registered on the MCP server.
    • This identifier should be independent of the human-readable tool name.
    • Use it as the primary reference for routing, versioning, and lookup.
  • Store the GUID in a canonical registry, and reject attempts to re-register the same GUID from unauthorized sources.

2. Apply strict naming policies

  • Define a tool naming policy that:
    • Disallows ambiguous names (e.g., visually similar characters like l, 1, or I).
    • Prevents reuse of names across different tool owners.
    • Prohibits Unicode homoglyphs or encoding tricks that could obfuscate intent.
  • Enforce minimum and maximum lengths, character set restrictions, and optionally namespacing (e.g., org/tool-name) to reduce collisions.

3. Authenticate tool ownership during registration

  • Require MCP tool providers to authenticate when registering or updating tools.
    • Use API keys, OAuth client credentials, or signed metadata headers.
  • Ensure that each tool name or GUID is bound to a specific authenticated identity or organization.

4. Detect and reject duplicates and lookalikes

  • Implement a fuzzy matching or similarity check (e.g., Levenshtein distance) to detect names that are visually or semantically similar to existing tools.
  • Flag suspicious tool names for manual review, especially if they closely resemble well-known or existing tool identifiers.

References

  • Enterprise-Grade Security for the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Frameworks and Mitigation Strategies
