usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of service via context overload
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could overwhelm the MCP server by inundating it with excessive requests for context creation or updates, leading to exhaustion of CPU, memory, and I/O resources, ultimately causing disruption of service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This type of attack could be initiated by malicious actors over the network who take advantage of vulnerabilities in request handling mechanisms, potentially employing botnets to amplify the attack traffic.
Impacts
The primary impact of such an attack would be the degradation or complete interruption of the service provided by the MCP server, affecting all dependent applications and potentially leading to significant operational and financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example scenario could involve an attacker deploying a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, leveraging a botnet to send a large volume of context creation requests to the MCP server simultaneously, saturating its computational resources and knocking it offline.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service||ATLAS - AML.T0029 - Denial of AI Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks triggering unauthorized actions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could craft messages containing hidden instructions that an AI assistant interprets, leading to unintended or malicious MCP server commands being executed without user intent.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may exploit vulnerabilities in AI assistants to inject covert commands within seemingly benign messages, tricking the MCP server into executing them.
Impacts
This could potentially result in unauthorized access, data corruption, or other malicious activities that compromise the server's integrity and security.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sends an email to a user, embedding hidden commands in the text that, when read by an AI assistant, result in unauthorized changes to the MCP server settings.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: MCP server compromise and token mass exfiltration
threat.desc:
General threat description
An unauthorized access to an MCP server can potentially lead to a security breach where attackers gain access to stored authentication tokens. This creates a vulnerability across multiple services, enabling attackers to perform various unauthorized actions and maintain persistent access despite any password changes.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in the MCP server or use stolen credentials to gain access. They might also employ phishing, malware, or other social engineering tactics to obtain initial unauthorized entry.
Impacts
Once compromised, attackers can perform broad unauthorized actions, leading to data breaches, service disruptions, or system manipulation. The persistent access provided by authentication tokens exacerbates the risk, even when users change their passwords.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker breaches an MCP server and retrieves stored authentication tokens. Using these tokens, the attacker gains unauthorized access to various services linked to the server, manipulating data or extracting sensitive information without being detected. Even after a user changes their password, the attacker's access remains, causing ongoing security concerns.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1558 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets||ATLAS - AML.TA0013 - Credential Access||ATLAS - AML.T0024.002 - Extract AI Model

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Uncontrolled LLM response behavior
threat.desc:
General threat description

LLMs integrated with MCP servers may produce unsafe outputs if prompted with poisoned input or ambiguous instructions. Even with a validated schema, the model can be tricked into leaking sensitive data (e.g., environment variables, access tokens) or generating unsafe commands when no output filtering or containment strategy is in place.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

Attackers can craft malicious tool descriptions or leverage prompt injection within the LLM context to elicit harmful or confidential responses. These inputs may be hidden in descriptions, default values, or external context files that the LLM processes during tool reasoning. The attacker may not even need the tool to be invoked the LLM's output generation alone can be sufficient.

Impacts

The LLM could leak credentials, reveal system configuration, or generate outputs that, if executed by another component, lead to data loss or system compromise. This undermines the confidentiality of the environment and could impact trust in LLM-assisted decision-making pipelines.

Example attack scenarios

  • A tool includes a description that encourages the LLM to add ~/.ssh/id_rsa content into a function call. Even though the tool is never used, the LLM still generates the output, revealing the private key.
  • A prompt injection embedded in a context file causes the LLM to summarize sensitive internal policy details and output them to an external channel.
  • A malicious schema sets a default value that includes shell command syntax, which is later reflected in LLM output in a code-generation setting.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Unauthorized access to sensitive context information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without fine-grained access controls, unauthorized parties could retrieve or infer sensitive model context parameters and stored service tokens.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, hackers, or unauthorized external users exploiting weak access control measures and obtaining direct or indirect access to model context parameters and service tokens through available interfaces or backdoors.
Impacts
Potential exposure of sensitive data, loss of data integrity, unauthorized transaction execution, exploitation of services, reputational damage, and financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An external attacker accesses the server using a compromised account and retrieves sensitive model parameters. Similarly, an insider with limited access exploits lack of proper access restrictions to infer and misuse stored service tokens, leading to unauthorized activities within the system.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores||ATLAS - AML.T0016 - Obtain Capabilities||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Excessive permission scope and data aggregation risk
threat.desc:
General threat description
MCP servers requesting overly broad access scopes consolidate sensitive data from multiple services, creating risks of mass data exfiltration, privacy violations, and sophisticated correlation attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers could exploit overly broad access scopes requested by MCP servers to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. They may use phishing, malware, or other attack vectors to compromise the server.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include mass data exfiltration, breaches of user privacy, potential legal penalties, and an increased risk of data correlation attacks that could lead to further vulnerabilities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an MCP server due to weak access controls and uses the overly broad scopes to exfiltrate sensitive personal data across interconnected services, leading to financial and reputational damage to the affected organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage||ATLAS - AML.T0048.003 - User Harm

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Spoofing of context request origin
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could impersonate a trusted client to deliver harmful context requests to the MCP server, resulting in illicit access to model context configurations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The primary threat agents include malicious actors with the capability to masquerade as legitimate clients. This can occur through phishing, credential theft, or exploiting weak authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
The attack might lead to unauthorized modifications of model configurations, potentially resulting in incorrect processing, data corruption, or leakage of sensitive information. It can also undermine the integrity and availability of the server.
Example Attack Scenarios
A cybercriminal uses stolen credentials to mimic a trusted client, submitting bogus configuration requests that cause disruptions in the server's operations. Alternatively, an attacker exploits a vulnerability in an authentication protocol, enabling them to alter model contexts and extract confidential data without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Token theft leading to account takeover
threat.desc:
General threat description
If an OAuth token stored by the MCP server is stolen, attackers could impersonate the victim across connected services without triggering typical login alerts, enabling stealthy access and data exfiltration.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can gain access to stored OAuth tokens through weaknesses in server security, such as missing patches, weak authentication methods, or vulnerabilities in third-party applications interacting with the server.
Impacts
Stolen tokens can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data and systems, compromising user privacy, data integrity, and potentially leading to significant data breaches without raising immediate suspicion.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker obtains an OAuth token by exploiting a vulnerability in the MCP server's software. They use this token to gain unauthorized access to a connected service, extract sensitive data, and perform actions as the legitimate user, all while bypassing traditional login detection mechanisms.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0021 - Establish Accounts

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Malicious or untrusted tool definitions
threat.desc:
General threat description

Attackers may exploit weaknesses in the way MCP servers accept and validate tool definitions by injecting malicious content or replacing previously trusted schemas. This includes manipulating tool descriptions, schema parameters (e.g., default, required, enum), or swapping approved tool versions for tampered ones. Additionally, attackers might register tools with names that mimic trusted ones to hijack requests.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

Malicious developers, insiders, or remote attackers could leverage poorly enforced schema validation and naming controls to deliver manipulated schemas to the MCP server. These could be submitted during tool registration, retrieved from compromised or spoofed endpoints, or injected via collaborative environments.

Impacts

The LLM may misinterpret the schema content and perform unauthorized actions, expose internal logic, or become misaligned with its intended behavior. The overall trust model between the LLM and its tools may be undermined, potentially enabling lateral movement, command injection, or persistence of malicious tool behavior over time.

Example attack scenarios

  • An attacker submits a tool with a valid-looking schema that includes a default parameter containing a command to extract local files, which the LLM incorporates into a generated output.
  • A trusted tool initially approved is later updated with a malicious version on the server, without alerting the clientcausing the LLM to execute unintended logic.
  • A typosquatting attack registers a tool named translate-docs to impersonate a legitimate translate_docs, capturing traffic and injecting backdoors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1659 - Content Injection||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection||ATLAS - AML.T0016 - Obtain Capabilities

threat.name: Tampering with context data in transit
threat.desc:
General threat description
Context payloads sent between clients and the MCP server are susceptible to tampering if the communication channels are not properly secured. This could result in the modification or poisoning of model contexts.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers could intercept and alter context data in transit between clients and the server if protective measures such as encryption and integrity checks are not implemented effectively.
Impacts
Such tampering could compromise the integrity of the model contexts, potentially leading to incorrect data processing, decision-making errors, and a loss of trust in the system.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could perform a man-in-the-middle attack to intercept and modify context payloads being exchanged between a client application and the MCP server, injecting malicious data or altering the context to cause undesired or harmful outcomes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1040 - Network Sniffing||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATLAS - AML.T0043.003 - Manual Modification

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

countermeasure.name: Enable automated image scanning for ECR repositories
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain a secure container environment in AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry), configure automated image scans to detect vulnerabilities in container images upon push and on a regular schedule. This helps identify and mitigate potential security threats before deploying images.

Enable Image Scanning on Push:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to your ECR repositories and enable the "Scan on Push" option. This setting ensures that each image is automatically scanned for vulnerabilities as soon as it is pushed to the repository.

Schedule Regular Image Scans:

  • Use AWS ECR's built-in capabilities to schedule periodic re-scans of all images. This is important for detecting newly discovered vulnerabilities in already stored images.

Set Up Notifications for Vulnerability Findings:

  • Configure Amazon SNS (Simple Notification Service) to send alerts for critical vulnerabilities detected in images. Integrate these notifications with your security information and event management (SIEM) tools or incident response workflows.

Review and Act on Scan Reports:

  • Regularly review vulnerability reports generated by ECR image scans. Prioritize remediation efforts for high and critical severity findings to minimize security risks.

Implement Automated Remediation Actions:

  • Integrate image scanning results with CI/CD pipelines to automatically block the deployment of images with high-severity vulnerabilities until they are resolved.

reference.name: Scan images for software vulnerabilities in Amazon ECR

countermeasure.name: Enable notifications for key ECR repository events
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and monitoring of AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry), configure ECR to send notifications for key repository events such as image push, pull, or deletion activities. This helps in promptly detecting unauthorized access or suspicious activities and allows for immediate response.

Set Up Amazon SNS for Notifications:

  • Create an Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic to handle notifications for ECR events. Ensure the SNS topic is configured to send alerts via email, SMS, or integrate with other monitoring tools as needed.

Configure ECR Event Rules:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the ECR service and set up event rules for important repository actions. Specify events such as image push, pull, and deletion activities to trigger notifications.

Integrate with CloudWatch Events:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch Events to capture ECR repository events and route them to the SNS topic. This integration allows for real-time monitoring of repository activities and automated alerts.

Customize Notification Settings:

  • Tailor notification settings to match your organizations security requirements. For example, set high-priority alerts for image deletions or pulls from unexpected IP addresses or regions.

reference.name: Amazon ECR events and EventBridge

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all communications with ECR
countermeasure.desc:
To secure data in transit and prevent interception, ensure that all communications with AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) use HTTPS. This encrypts the data transferred between ECR and other services or clients, protecting it from eavesdropping and tampering by malicious actors.

Require HTTPS for ECR Endpoints:

  • Configure all client applications, scripts, and automation tools interacting with AWS ECR to use HTTPS endpoints (https://) rather than HTTP. This ensures that all API calls and data transfers are encrypted.

Enforce Secure Protocols:

  • Update all Docker clients and other tools that interact with ECR to support and use only secure protocols, ensuring compatibility with HTTPS. Avoid using outdated or insecure versions of Docker that do not enforce HTTPS.

Restrict Direct Internet Access:

  • For environments that do not require public internet access, use VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) to connect to ECR securely without traversing the public internet. This further enhances the security of data in transit by keeping traffic within the AWS network.

Monitor Network Traffic for Compliance:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and VPC Flow Logs to monitor network traffic and ensure that all communications with ECR repositories are using HTTPS. Set up alerts for any traffic detected over non-secure HTTP connections.

reference.name: Security in Amazon Elastic Container Registry

countermeasure.name: Implement lifecycle policies for automated image retention management
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain control over AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repository contents and reduce the risk of accidental deletion, configure lifecycle policies to automate image retention management. This ensures that only relevant and necessary images are retained, optimizing storage and enhancing security.

Define Lifecycle Policies:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to your ECR repository and create lifecycle policies to specify image retention rules. Define policies based on image tags, age, or count to ensure that older, unused, or untagged images are automatically removed.

Set Retention Criteria:

  • Establish criteria for retaining images, such as keeping only the latest versions, retaining images used in production, or keeping images for a specified period (e.g., 30 days). Ensure these criteria align with your organizations deployment and security policies.

Apply Policies to Repositories:

  • Apply the defined lifecycle policies to all relevant ECR repositories to automate the cleanup process and prevent the accumulation of outdated or unused images.

Monitor and Adjust Policies:

  • Regularly review lifecycle policy logs and adjust policies as needed to accommodate changes in deployment practices, security requirements, or business needs.

Integrate with DevOps Workflows:

  • Ensure that lifecycle policies are integrated with your DevOps workflows to avoid unintentional removal of images required for CI/CD pipelines. Communicate policy details to development teams to align image usage with retention rules.

reference.name: Automate the cleanup of images by using lifecycle policies in Amazon ECR

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies to control access to ECR repositories
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repositories, use resource-based policies to control access, ensuring that only authorized users and roles have the necessary permissions to interact with the repositories. This helps prevent unauthorized access and actions such as pulling, pushing, or deleting container images.

Define Resource-Based Policies:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the ECR service and create resource-based policies for each repository. These policies should specify who (users, roles, AWS accounts) can access the repository and what actions (e.g., push, pull, delete) they are allowed to perform.

Grant Least Privilege Access:

  • Configure the policies to follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their specific tasks. Avoid using overly broad permissions that could lead to unauthorized access.

Restrict Cross-Account Access:

  • If cross-account access is required, specify the exact AWS accounts and IAM roles that are allowed access to the ECR repository. Use conditions within the policy to restrict access based on specific criteria such as IP addresses or request time.

Apply and Review Policies Regularly:

  • Apply the resource-based policies to each ECR repository and regularly review them to ensure they align with the current security requirements and organizational policies. Update the policies as needed to accommodate changes in user roles or security needs.

Monitor Access and Usage:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch to monitor access to ECR repositories and log all interactions. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or changes to repository settings.

reference.name: Private repository policies in Amazon ECR

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insecure deletion of repository resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Insecure Deletion of Repository Resources" refers to the risk of accidental or malicious deletion of container images and repositories in AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) without proper authorization or safeguards. This could result in the loss of critical container images, disruption of application deployments, and potential security vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, negligent administrators, external attackers with unauthorized access.
  • Vectors:
    • Misconfigured IAM policies allowing unauthorized or overly broad deletion permissions.
    • Lack of lifecycle policies or version control, leading to accidental deletions.
    • Exploitation of compromised credentials with deletion access.

Impacts:

  • Data Loss: Permanent deletion of critical container images, resulting in the inability to deploy or rollback applications.
  • Operational Disruption: Deletion of images can disrupt CI/CD pipelines, causing delays in application deployments and service outages.
  • Security Risks: Deletion of secure, trusted images could lead to the deployment of unvetted or compromised images.
  • Compliance Issues: Uncontrolled deletions may violate data retention policies or regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Accidental Deletion: An administrator mistakenly deletes a repository containing critical images due to a lack of lifecycle management or version control, causing significant deployment issues.
  • Malicious Insider Action: A disgruntled employee with deletion access intentionally deletes key images from ECR, disrupting application deployments and causing potential security breaches.
  • Compromised Account: An attacker uses compromised credentials with deletion permissions to remove important images, leading to application downtime and security exposure.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Use of vulnerable container images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Using vulnerable container images in AWS ECR can expose applications to security risks. Vulnerabilities may come from outdated software, insecure dependencies, or malicious code within the images, allowing attackers to exploit these weaknesses.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors:
    • Pulling images from untrusted or public sources.
    • Deploying images without vulnerability scans.
    • Using outdated base images or insecure dependencies.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Exploitation of vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access or execute malicious code.
  • Data Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive data within compromised containers.
  • Operational Disruption: Potential for Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks or performance degradation.
  • Compliance Violations: Non-compliance with security regulations due to using unpatched images.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Outdated Image Exploit: An unpatched base image with a critical vulnerability is exploited, allowing an attacker to gain control over the container.
  • Malware in Unscanned Image: A container image containing malware is deployed without a security scan, leading to data exfiltration.
  • Insecure Dependencies: A container uses outdated libraries, which are exploited by attackers to access the backend database and steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1609 - Container Administration Command

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure data transfer
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Insecure Data Transfer" refers to the risk of data being transmitted between AWS ECR and other services without adequate encryption. If data is transferred over insecure channels, it can be intercepted, modified, or stolen by malicious actors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Transmitting data between ECR and other services without using HTTPS.
    • Misconfigured network settings that allow unsecured communication.
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks exploiting unencrypted traffic.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Interception of sensitive data in transit, such as container images, credentials, or configuration details.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Modification of data during transfer, leading to corrupted or maliciously altered images.
  • Service Disruption: Potential for unauthorized access or manipulation of container images, impacting service availability.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Intercepted Credentials: An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic between ECR and a client, capturing sensitive credentials used for authentication and gaining unauthorized access.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: A MitM attack is executed on unsecured communications, allowing an attacker to modify container images in transit, injecting malicious code.
  • Unauthorized Access via Unsecured Connection: An insider exploits a misconfigured network setting to access and download sensitive images from ECR without proper authorization.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to ECR repositories
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Unauthorized Access to ECR Repositories" refers to the risk of unauthorized users gaining access to AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repositories. This unauthorized access could lead to actions such as pulling, pushing, or deleting container images without proper authorization, potentially compromising the security and integrity of applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized external users.
  • Vectors:
    • Misconfigured IAM policies or repository permissions allowing overly broad access.
    • Exploitation of compromised credentials with elevated privileges.
    • Inadequate use of resource-based policies, allowing unintended access.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized users could pull sensitive or proprietary images, exposing them to external threats.
  • Data Manipulation: Attackers might push malicious images or delete critical images, leading to the deployment of compromised containers.
  • Operational Disruption: Deletion or tampering with images could disrupt application deployment pipelines, causing downtime.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized access can lead to non-compliance with data protection and security standards.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses compromised credentials to access an ECR repository and pulls sensitive container images, exposing proprietary code or configurations.
  • Overly Permissive Policies: A repository is configured with overly permissive IAM policies that inadvertently grant public access, allowing unauthorized users to pull or push images without restriction.
  • Insider Threat: A malicious insider with unauthorized access to ECR repositories deletes critical images or replaces them with tampered versions, leading to potential security breaches and operational issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring of repository activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Monitoring of Repository Activities" refers to the absence of adequate logging and monitoring for actions taken within AWS ECR repositories. Without proper monitoring, unauthorized access, suspicious activities, or potential security incidents such as unauthorized image pushes, pulls, or deletions may go undetected.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors:
    • Lack of configured logging for ECR repository actions.
    • No alerting mechanisms for critical events such as unauthorized access attempts or deletions.
    • Insufficient visibility into repository activities, leading to undetected malicious actions.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Lack of detection for unauthorized access attempts, potentially compromising repository security.
  • Data Loss: Undetected deletions or modifications of container images can lead to data loss or deployment of compromised images.
  • Compliance Violations: Failing to monitor repository activities may result in non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Undetected Unauthorized Access: An external attacker gains unauthorized access to an ECR repository but remains undetected due to lack of monitoring, allowing for repeated unauthorized activities.
  • Malicious Insider Deletion: A disgruntled insider deletes critical images from the repository. Without monitoring, the action is not immediately noticed, causing operational disruptions.
  • Image Tampering: An attacker modifies images within the repository to inject malicious code. Due to insufficient monitoring, these changes go unnoticed until the compromised images are deployed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565.003 - Runtime Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

countermeasure.name: Configure public IP addresses only for necessary ELBs
countermeasure.desc: Only configure public IP addresses on Elastic Load Balancers (ELBs) that need to accept incoming requests from outside the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). This minimizes exposure to the internet and reduces the risk of unauthorized access. To implement this, ensure that ELBs without the requirement for public access are assigned private IP addresses. For ELBs requiring public access, carefully review and restrict the associated security group rules to allow only necessary traffic. Regularly audit and validate the configuration to maintain compliance with security best practices.

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Define network ACLs to control access to the VPC
countermeasure.desc: Define network Access Control Lists (ACLs) to control access to your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). Network ACLs provide an additional layer of security by acting as a stateless firewall for controlling inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level. To implement this, create custom network ACLs with specific rules to allow or deny traffic based on protocol, port number, and source/destination IP addresses. Apply these ACLs to your VPC subnets to enforce stringent access controls and protect your resources from unauthorized access.

reference.name: Control subnet traffic with network access control lists

countermeasure.name: Define security groups to control access to AWS resources
countermeasure.desc: Define security groups to control access to AWS resources. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify rules that permit or deny inbound and outbound traffic to and from your resources. To implement this, create security groups with specific rules that allow only necessary traffic based on protocol, port number, and source/destination IP addresses. Apply these security groups to your AWS resources, such as EC2 instances and ELBs, to enforce stringent access controls and enhance security.

reference.name: Security in Elastic Load Balancing

countermeasure.name: Enable authentication on ALB listeners to validate incoming requests
countermeasure.desc: Enable authentication on Application Load Balancer (ALB) listeners to validate all incoming requests and offload the authentication burden from the application. This ensures that only authenticated users can access your services, enhancing security and reducing the load on backend applications. To implement this, configure the ALB to use an authentication provider such as Amazon Cognito or a third-party provider via OpenID Connect. Set up authentication rules in the ALB listener settings to enforce user authentication before allowing access to the target application.

reference.name: Authenticate users using an Application Load Balancer

countermeasure.name: Enable Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) for ELB
countermeasure.desc: Enable Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) for AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to ensure that session keys cannot be compromised even if the server's long-term key is. PFS enhances the security of encrypted communications by generating unique session keys for each connection, preventing the decryption of past sessions in the event of key compromise. To implement this, configure your ELB to use TLS cipher suites that support PFS, such as those using Diffie-Hellman key exchange. Regularly review and update your cipher suite configurations to maintain strong encryption standards.

reference.name: Security in Elastic Load Balancing

countermeasure.name: Ensure encrypted communication for ELB listeners
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that listeners on the AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) support and require encrypted communication using TLS or HTTPS. This guarantees that data transmitted between clients and the load balancer is secure. To implement this, configure your ELB to use TLS/HTTPS listeners by creating and uploading an SSL/TLS certificate in AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) and then attaching the certificate to the ELB listener. Update your application settings to only accept secure connections.

reference.name: Data protection in Elastic Load Balancing

countermeasure.name: Restrict port and IP address ranges as much as possible
countermeasure.desc: Restrict port and IP address ranges as much as possible to minimize the attack surface and enhance the security of your AWS resources. This involves configuring security groups and network ACLs to allow only the necessary ports and specific IP ranges required for your application to function. By limiting the open ports and allowed IP addresses, you reduce the risk of unauthorized access and potential exploitation of vulnerabilities. Regularly review and update these rules to ensure they align with the current security requirements.

This enhances security by filtering out malicious traffic and reducing the risk of attacks. To implement this, configure AWS WAF with rules that specify allowed and blocked IP ranges, define geo-location restrictions, and create custom conditions based on your security requirements. Associate the WAF with your ELB to enforce these rules and monitor the traffic for compliance and potential threats. Regularly update and review the rules to maintain effective protection.

countermeasure.name: Utilize interface endpoints for secure ELB access within VPC
countermeasure.desc: To enhance security for AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB), configure and use interface endpoints to securely access the ELB from within your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). This ensures that all communication between the ELB and its clients remains within the AWS network, reducing exposure to the internet and minimizing the risk of unauthorized access. To implement this, create an interface VPC endpoint for ELB, configure your routing tables, and update security group rules to allow traffic from the endpoint.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unrestricted incoming requests
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrestricted incoming requests to an AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) can lead to the acceptance of potentially malicious traffic, increasing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, and other security incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious actors, automated bots, and unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Sending a high volume of requests, probing for vulnerabilities, attempting various attack patterns such as SQL injection, XSS, and DDoS.

Impacts

  • Security Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive data or systems.
  • Service Disruptions: Overloaded ELB leading to denial of service.
  • Data Loss/Corruption: Potential manipulation or loss of critical data.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. DDoS Attack: Attackers flood the ELB with a high volume of requests, overwhelming the system and causing service outages.
  2. Probing for Vulnerabilities: Attackers send a variety of requests to identify exploitable weaknesses in the web applications behind the ELB.
  3. Automated Attacks: Bots continuously send requests to perform brute force login attempts or exploit known vulnerabilities.

Implementing robust filtering, access control mechanisms, and monitoring can mitigate these threats.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access via internet
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access via the internet to AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) can result in unapproved users gaining control over your load balancers, potentially leading to data breaches, service disruptions, and other security incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Hackers, cybercriminals, unauthorized third parties.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting public-facing interfaces, leveraging exposed credentials, targeting misconfigured security settings.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized entities.
  • Service Disruptions: Potential interruption of service due to unauthorized configuration changes or attacks.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with data breaches, legal penalties, and recovery efforts.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and market reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Credential Theft: An attacker gains access to exposed credentials and uses them to access and manipulate ELB settings.
  2. Exploiting Public Endpoints: A hacker identifies and exploits vulnerabilities in publicly accessible ELB endpoints to gain unauthorized access.
  3. Misconfiguration Exploits: Attackers take advantage of improperly configured security groups or access controls to gain access and disrupt services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Excessive access permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Excessive access permissions occur when users or systems have more access rights than necessary, increasing the risk of unauthorized activities, data breaches, and compromised security.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Internal employees, malicious insiders, external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting over-permissive roles, gaining unauthorized access through compromised credentials, privilege escalation.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Misuse of Resources: Abuse of excessive permissions for malicious activities.
  • Compliance Violations: Failing to meet regulatory requirements for data protection.
  • Operational Disruptions: Unauthorized changes leading to system instability or downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Insider Threat: An employee with excessive permissions accesses and exfiltrates confidential data.
  2. Compromised Account: An external attacker exploits compromised credentials with excessive permissions to manipulate or delete critical data.
  3. Privilege Escalation: An attacker exploits a vulnerability to escalate privileges and gain full control over the system or sensitive resources.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted communication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted communication between clients and AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) can be intercepted by malicious actors, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data and potential manipulation of data in transit.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Hackers, cybercriminals, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted data via man-in-the-middle attacks, eavesdropping on network traffic, exploiting unsecured communication channels.

Impact

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive information such as login credentials, personal data, and confidential business information.
  • Data Integrity: Risk of data being tampered with or altered during transmission.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to comply with data protection regulations requiring encryption.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts unencrypted communications between a client and the load balancer, gaining access to sensitive data.
  2. Eavesdropping: Unauthorized entities listen to network traffic, capturing unencrypted information such as usernames, passwords, and financial data.
  3. Session Hijacking: An attacker exploits unencrypted sessions to hijack and take control of an active user session, performing actions on behalf of the user.

Ensuring all communications are encrypted using TLS or HTTPS is critical to mitigating these threats.

threat.name: Unrestricted public access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrestricted public access to AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) can expose the load balancer and associated resources to unauthorized users, leading to potential security breaches, data theft, and service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Hackers, malicious actors, automated bots.
  • Attack Vectors: Scanning for publicly accessible endpoints, exploiting open ports, sending malicious requests to publicly exposed ELB instances.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive data through unauthorized access.
  • Service Disruptions: Potential denial of service (DoS) attacks leading to downtime.
  • Unauthorized Modifications: Malicious changes to configurations or data by unauthorized users.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Port Scanning: An attacker scans for open ports on a publicly accessible ELB and uses identified vulnerabilities to gain access.
  2. Exploitation of Public IPs: Attackers leverage public IP addresses of ELB to launch attacks on backend services.
  3. Malicious Requests: Automated bots send a flood of requests to overwhelm the load balancer, causing performance degradation or outages.

Mitigating this threat involves restricting public access, using security groups, and placing ELB within a VPC.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1065 - Uncommonly Used Port

threat.name: Vulnerability to forward secrecy attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Forward secrecy attacks exploit the lack of forward secrecy in cryptographic communications, compromising past session keys if a server's long-term private key is compromised. This can result in the decryption of previously recorded sessions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Advanced persistent threats (APTs), nation-state actors, cybercriminals.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromising the long-term private key, intercepting and storing encrypted traffic for later decryption.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Historical encrypted communications can be decrypted, exposing sensitive information.
  • Loss of Confidentiality: Long-term compromise of communication privacy.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to adhere to data protection standards requiring forward secrecy.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Key Compromise: An attacker gains access to the servers long-term private key and decrypts previously recorded sessions.
  2. Stored Traffic Decryption: An APT intercepts and stores encrypted traffic, later decrypting it using the compromised private key.
  3. Historical Data Exposure: Sensitive historical data, including passwords and confidential communications, are exposed through decryption of past sessions.

Mitigating this threat involves enabling Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) in TLS configurations to ensure session keys are not compromised even if the server's long-term key is.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1212 - Exploitation for Credential Access

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Weak authentication for ingress traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Weak authentication for ingress traffic to AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) can allow unauthorized access, posing significant risks to security and data integrity. Without robust authentication, malicious actors can bypass security controls, leading to potential breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Hackers, malicious insiders, automated bots.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak or misconfigured authentication mechanisms, brute force attacks, credential stuffing.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Malicious actors gain access to sensitive systems and data.
  • Data Breaches: Exposure of confidential information.
  • Service Disruption: Potential compromise and disruption of services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to guess passwords and gain access through weak authentication.
  2. Credential Stuffing: An attacker uses stolen credentials from other breaches to gain unauthorized access.
  3. Misconfiguration Exploit: An attacker exploits misconfigured authentication settings to bypass security controls.

Mitigating this threat involves enforcing strong authentication mechanisms, such as OAuth or OpenID Connect, and integrating identity providers for robust access control.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-695
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-695: Use of Low-Level Functionality The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate. The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms, introduce exploitable inconsistencies, or otherwise expose the functionality to attack.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Activate deletion protection for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Enable deletion protection on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to prevent accidental or unauthorized removal of the load balancer. This setting adds an additional layer of security by ensuring that critical load balancer configurations cannot be deleted without explicit authorization. Activating deletion protection helps safeguard against human error, malicious actions, and potential service disruptions. Regularly review the status of deletion protection to confirm it remains enabled, ensuring continuous protection of your ALB and the applications it supports.

reference.name: Application Load Balancers

countermeasure.name: Configure strictest desync mitigation mode for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Set your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to operate using the strictest desynchronization (desync) mitigation mode available. This configuration helps defend against HTTP request smuggling and other desynchronization attacks that can exploit differences in how HTTP requests are processed between clients and servers. By enabling the strictest desync mitigation mode, you ensure that the ALB consistently handles incoming traffic in a secure manner, reducing the risk of these attacks and maintaining the integrity of data transmission. Regularly review and update this setting to align with best practices and evolving security threats.

reference.name: Application Load Balancers

countermeasure.name: Deploy AWS WAF with managed rules to protect applications behind your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Implement AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) in conjunction with your AWS Application Load Balancer to protect web applications from common web exploits and vulnerabilities. Utilize AWS WAF's managed rule sets to automatically block known threats, such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and other common attacks, before they reach your application. Configure and customize WAF rules based on the specific needs of your application to ensure comprehensive protection. Regularly review and update the WAF rules to adapt to new threats and application changes, ensuring continuous security. Integrate WAF logging with AWS CloudWatch for monitoring and alerting on suspicious activity.

reference.name: Web Application Firewall, Web API Protection - AWS WAF

countermeasure.name: Enable access logging for your Application Load Balancer and integrate with CloudWatch and CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc: Enable access logging on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to capture detailed records of all incoming traffic. Integrate these logs with AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail to monitor for suspicious activities and unauthorized access attempts. Set up automated alerts within CloudWatch to notify your team of any anomalies or potential security incidents. Regularly review the access logs to identify patterns or activities that may indicate security threats, and take proactive measures to address any identified risks. This control ensures that all traffic through the ALB is tracked and analyzed, enhancing the security and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable access logs for your Application Load Balancer

countermeasure.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that cross-zone load balancing is enabled on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to evenly distribute incoming traffic across all available zones within the region. This configuration enhances fault tolerance by preventing any single availability zone from becoming a bottleneck or single point of failure. It also improves resource efficiency by balancing the load across multiple zones, ensuring optimal performance and reducing the risk of overloading individual resources. Regularly verify that cross-zone load balancing is enabled and functioning as intended to maintain high availability and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental or malicious deletion of Load Balancer
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Accidental or malicious deletion of an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) occurs when the load balancer is unintentionally or deliberately removed, disrupting traffic distribution and causing service outages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Human Error: Mistaken deletion during routine tasks.
  • Malicious Insider: An authorized user intentionally deletes the ALB.
  • Compromised Credentials: Attackers gain unauthorized access and delete the ALB.

Impacts

  • Service Downtime: Immediate interruption in traffic routing, leading to application unavailability.
  • Revenue Loss: Downtime can lead to financial losses and damage to customer trust.
  • Operational Disruption: Resources are diverted to restore service, causing further delays.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental Deletion: An admin mistakenly deletes the ALB during maintenance, causing downtime until reconfiguration.
  2. Malicious Insider: A disgruntled employee deletes the ALB to cause service outages.
  3. Credential Compromise: An attacker deletes the ALB after gaining unauthorized access to the AWS console.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Lack of logging and monitoring in AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refers to the absence or inadequacy of tracking and reviewing activities related to the ALB. Without proper logging, security incidents, misconfigurations, or unauthorized access attempts may go undetected, leaving the system vulnerable to prolonged risks and making it difficult to investigate incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Logging and monitoring features not properly enabled or configured.
  • Negligence: Failure to regularly review logs or set up alerts for suspicious activities.
  • Malicious Actors: Exploiting the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions undetected.

Impacts

  • Undetected Security Incidents: Without logs, security breaches can go unnoticed.
  • Difficulty in Incident Response: Lack of detailed logs complicates forensic investigations and response efforts.
  • Non-Compliance: Failure to maintain proper logging may lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Undetected Breach: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an application behind the ALB, but due to lack of logging, the breach remains unnoticed for an extended period.
  2. Misconfiguration Overlooked: A misconfiguration in the ALB allows traffic that should have been blocked. Without monitoring, this issue persists, exposing the application to potential attacks.
  3. Failed Audit: During a compliance audit, the organization fails to provide adequate logs for the ALB, leading to penalties or loss of certification.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure cross-zone Load Balancing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure cross-zone load balancing in AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refers to the improper configuration of traffic distribution across multiple availability zones. If cross-zone load balancing is not enabled or is misconfigured, traffic may be unevenly distributed, leading to potential single points of failure, inefficient resource utilization, and reduced fault tolerance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Failure to enable cross-zone load balancing or incorrect settings that prevent proper traffic distribution.
  • Resource Limitations: Uneven distribution of traffic that causes some zones to be overburdened while others remain underutilized.
  • Fault Tolerance Issues: Lack of redundancy due to improper load balancing can make the system vulnerable to zone failures.

Impacts

  • Single Points of Failure: Without proper cross-zone balancing, a failure in a heavily burdened zone can lead to significant service disruption.
  • Inefficient Resource Utilization: Overloaded zones can lead to poor performance and increased latency, while underutilized zones waste resources.
  • Reduced Fault Tolerance: The inability to distribute traffic evenly across zones can reduce the overall fault tolerance of the application, making it more susceptible to outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Zone Failure: Cross-zone load balancing is disabled, and most traffic is routed to a single availability zone. When that zone experiences an outage, the application becomes unavailable.
  2. Performance Degradation: A misconfigured ALB routes most traffic to one zone, overloading instances in that zone while instances in other zones remain idle, leading to slow response times and poor user experience.
  3. Increased Latency: Due to improper load balancing, some users experience higher latency because their requests are handled by overburdened instances in a particular zone, while other instances are underused.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

threat.name: Vulnerabilities in web applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Vulnerabilities in web applications behind an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refer to security weaknesses in the applications that can be exploited by attackers. These vulnerabilities may include SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), insecure deserialization, and other common web application flaws. If not properly mitigated, these vulnerabilities can be exploited to compromise the application, steal data, or gain unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Attackers actively scan for and exploit vulnerabilities in web applications to gain unauthorized access or cause harm.
  • Automated Bots: Bots can systematically probe web applications for known vulnerabilities and exploit them if found.
  • Inadequate Security Practices: Development teams may inadvertently introduce vulnerabilities through coding errors or inadequate security testing.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information may be accessed or stolen, leading to significant financial and reputational damage.
  • Application Compromise: Attackers can gain control over the application, altering functionality or using it as a launching point for further attacks.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Exploited vulnerabilities can result in violations of data protection regulations, leading to fines and penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. SQL Injection: An attacker exploits a SQL injection vulnerability in the web application to access the backend database, stealing sensitive user information.
  2. Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): An attacker injects malicious scripts into a vulnerable web application, which are then executed in the browsers of unsuspecting users, leading to data theft or session hijacking.
  3. Insecure Deserialization: A vulnerability in the applications deserialization process is exploited by an attacker to execute arbitrary code, leading to complete system compromise.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Desynchronization attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Desynchronization attacks on AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) involve manipulating the sequence or synchronization of HTTP requests and responses, leading to vulnerabilities like HTTP request smuggling. These attacks can allow malicious actors to bypass security controls, inject malicious payloads, or interfere with normal application operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Attackers exploit gaps in how the ALB processes and synchronizes HTTP requests and responses.
  • Misconfiguration: Improper settings in the ALB that allow desync vulnerabilities to be exploited.
  • Complex Web Traffic: Applications with complex, multi-part requests that are more susceptible to desync issues.

Impacts

  • Bypassed Security Controls: Attackers can bypass firewalls or WAF rules, leading to potential data breaches or unauthorized actions.
  • Request Smuggling: Malicious actors can manipulate HTTP requests to perform actions they shouldn't be allowed to.
  • Service Disruption: Desync attacks can cause disruptions in how applications process web traffic, potentially leading to outages or degraded performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Request Smuggling: An attacker sends a specially crafted HTTP request that takes advantage of desynchronization, bypassing the WAF and gaining unauthorized access to sensitive application areas.
  2. Bypass Security Filters: Due to a desync issue, a malicious payload is able to slip through security filters that would normally block it, leading to data exfiltration.
  3. Service Degradation: A desynchronization attack causes the ALB to misroute traffic, leading to significant delays and potential service outages.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-347
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-347: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-708
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-708: Incorrect Ownership Assignment The product assigns an owner to a resource, but the owner is outside of the intended control sphere. This may allow the resource to be manipulated by actors outside of the intended control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Access controls for task management
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing access controls to limit who can create, modify, or delete scheduled tasks is essential to enhance the security of your system. Follow these steps to set up access controls effectively:

  1. Identify key users and roles:
    • Determine which users or roles need permission to create, modify, or delete scheduled tasks. Typically, this includes system administrators and specific maintenance personnel.
    • Ensure that these roles are clearly defined and documented in your system's access control policies.
  2. Set up role-based access control (RBAC):
    • Configure your system to use RBAC, assigning permissions based on the roles identified in the previous step.
    • For Windows systems, use Group Policy to set up and enforce these permissions. Refer to the User Rights Assignment in the Windows security policy settings.
    • In Linux or Unix-based systems, utilize user groups and modify /etc/sudoers or use access control lists (ACLs) to grant necessary permissions.
  3. Use built-in schedulers securely:
    • For Windows Task Scheduler, set task security options under the "General" tab:
      • Select "Run only when the user is logged on" or "Run whether the user is logged on or not" depending on the requirement, but ensure the appropriate user account is selected.
      • Use the "Change User or Group..." button to restrict tasks to specific users or service accounts.
    • For cron jobs in Unix/Linux, restrict job editing by setting proper file permissions for the crontab file. Example: 
      chmod 600 /var/spool/cron/crontabs/username
  4. Audit and monitor scheduled tasks:
    • Regularly review who has access to manage scheduled tasks and verify that these permissions are still valid.
    • Implement logging and monitoring to track changes to scheduled tasks. For instance, use Windows Event Viewer or auditing scripts in Unix to log access and modifications.
    • Establish alerts for unauthorized modifications or creations of scheduled tasks to respond promptly to potential security breaches.
  5. Training and awareness:
    • Conduct regular training sessions for users with access to scheduled tasks to ensure they understand the security policies and best practices.
    • Ensure that all new users and roles requiring access to scheduling functionalities undergo a thorough onboarding and training process.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
